  5821. I personally would benefit more from a smaller handle and harder bristles because my hair is thick even though it's short.
  5822. So, I dried my hair first -- left it a bit dump - and proceeded to use the air brush:
  5823. I have bought this hot air brush twice and both have burned out after only a few months of use.
  5824. My only complaint is that my thumb rests on the temperature/on/off switch and keeps turning it to cool.
  5825. the air is hot enough to give volume and jut product itself isn't too heavy to hold for extended period of time
  5826. Warranty helps and they take care of you but still sucks they blow out so quickly.
  5827. Does well, hair cannot be dripping wet when used, but does a spiffy Kubrick when I cannot do a full blowout with a round brush and separate dryer.
  5828. I have super thick hair
  5829. I have super thick curly hair
  5830. I have super thick, course hair that takes forever to straighten.
  5831. have super thick and curly indian hair
  5832. Other hot air curling burshes always leave my hair frizzy with lots of loose fly-away strands.
  5833. Previously I dryed my hair about 90% and then used large rollers for the last 10% of the drying process to get the volumn.
  5834. Pretty much stick straight, except for a couple of areas along the bottom that like to do this strange little wave, making my hair look more than a little crazy at times.
  5835. A little bit about my hair: I have naturally blond, long, and straight hair.
  5836. My fine hair takes a long time to dry (ask my hair dresser who can take 30-45 to dry and style it) and this drastically cuts down on the time and effort it takes while giving me the fuller hair that I like.
  5837. Using this product to dry your hair (unless it was short or very fine) would take a ridiculous amount of time to dry.
  5838. the handle on the 1.5&#34; size is a little large and might deter some owners.<br /><br
  5839. I let my hair mostly dry naturally as suggested in previous reviews but just couldn't get hair to grab in bristles without needing to touch end of device (which I knew would be very hot based on other comments).
  5840. I had a similar product previously that dried my hair very quickly and straightened at the same time.
  5841. I have very thick, fine hair.
  5842. Each strand of hair individually is fine, but I have very thick head of hair.
  5843. My hair has gone from straight with no wave to some wave and then to curls and now its a frizzy mess.
  5844. Not made of nearly the same long lasting material as they used to, but works well.
  5845. I don't think I'll be using this much because since it blows hot air outwards it leaves my hair frizzier than if I blow dried my hair inwards with a round brush and a hair dryer
  5846. Gives hair body and bounce without the harsh heat that typically dries out my fine, blonde hair.
  5847. wait a few minutes later to put the brush back on because the hair brush was hot.
  5848. It doesn't blow as much air as my old one and takes a little longer to dry my hair
  5849. Before I would blow dry with a round brush and then add some Velcro rollers and hit them with some heat to lock in a little more shape/volume and sometime use a curling iron too.
  5850. I let my hair dry at least 50% and then use this for a fabulous look - lots of compliments.
  5851. I used it in place of my regular hair dryer and my hair was very frizzy and still slightly damp after about 20 minutes with this.
  5852. only downside to this brush for me is that I have to let my hair dry naturally
  5853. I use this strictly for styling and dry my hair almost completely with my regular hair dryer.
  5854. Mission accomplished in less than ten minutes.
  5855. is that if you have long thick hair like i do, you will probably need to dry the hair around your scalp with a conventional hairdryer first, because at 500 watts i feel that it's kind of weak, & then dry off the rest with this hot air brush.
  5856. and sometimes I can only use one hand get ready since the other is needed to keep my son out of the toilet
  5857. If your hair is soaking wet or long and thick I'd suggest drying mostly with a regular hair dryer and then use this as a finishing or styling brush.
  5858. I first dry my hair upside down about 60-70%.
  5859. have very thick hair, so I always do a &#34;rough&#34; dry first, drying my hair about 75-80% before starting with the hot air brush.
  5860. Another disadvantage is that you can't remove the brush to clean or wash it - not good.
  5861. I simply do not have time to mess with my hair much in the morning
  5862. Controls frizz and makes it easy to avoid the weird waves and curls that occur near the roots with traditional hair drying.
  5863. My hair is thin & fine

  5865. I have thin, fine hair cut into a layered chin length bob.

  5868. I have both fine and thin hair
  5869. and I have thin fine hair

  5872. I have thin, fine hair, and this doesn't tangle or pull my hair at all.
  5873. I have thin, fine hair and this appliance
  5874. I have thin fine hair
  5875. I use a blow dryer and a large round
  5876. I got this little appliance, it's made my routine so much easier.
  5877. I understand that some other person might have tried it and returned it, but you don't send it off as new and unchecked.
  5878. The John Frieda JFHA5 Hot Air Brush style/dries my hair in half the time that it took me to dry with a drier and brush.
  5879. I would strongly suggest to John Frieda that the next model of this Hot Air Brush include a Cool-Shot BUTTON so that the user doesn't have to try to slide the panel options up and down while holding the Brush in difficult position.
  5880. I was curious how a brush drier would work on my hair (thick yet fine chin length bob-style).
  5881. that was much more expensive was huge and very hard to manage.
  5882. It's not hot enough to give a super styled look, but I use it for every day just to give a little curved shape to my hair.
  5883. As I don't have to shampoo daily, I can smooth out the 'bed hair' in minutes, something that was difficult with other hot air brushes I've used.
  5884. my hair turned very very rough just with one use ( I use good base products before using hot iron/curlers).
  5885. In reading the directions is recommends blow drying wet hair first to 80% dry and then using the Air Brush to style and dry hair the rest of the way.
  5886. This actually was much worse at that than a fine toothed comb and a regular blow dryer and they split once I was done.<br /><br />I
  5887. My hair is thick and it takes a little more time than hairdrying
  5888. My daughter has thick glossy hair and wanted to be able to put a little curl in her hair.
  5889. It does heat up and it will curl the ends, but I went back to my traditional blower and large vented round brush.
  5890. My hair took forever to dry despite being mostly dry because I had to take such small sections to get smooth results.
  5891. It's difficult to get to high heat without going to the cool air.
  5892. Is so big for thin fine short hair need to make a smaller one
  5893. My hair is thick but fine with crazy curls in the back underneath portion with waive and frizz on the top section, but you'd never know that now.
  5894. I bought because it is much gentler on my hair, no more little burns on my neck from a hot metal barrel.<br />When
  5895. The only downfalls I found were that it is a little clumsy (but I think this will lessen as I get used to using it) and I wish it has more of a tip on the end as I grab it out of habit from using a curling iron to stabilize it when rolling.
  5896. I always struggled with the whole hair dryer in one hand and brush in the other hand thing to dry my hair.
  5897. As other reviewers have said, this is made for hair that is mostly dry so keep your regular dryer on hand if you're ever in a real hurry.
  5898. Probably would need to blowdry a little first if you have super thick hair or usually need a high heat dryer.
  5899. It has good power and heat but the heat/power button is a bad design.

All Reviews

  1. I have had several round brush hair dryers before and was hoping to find one with more power. This one has even less than the one I had before. I have medium length thick hair. After 30 minutes of drying I still had to follow up with a regular blow dryer.
  2. Highly recommended to go to YouTube to search for some tutorial videos if you have never used similar product before. But, as said, as you started to use it in the right way, you will definitely fall in love with this product!
  3. Works well, does a great job.
  4. I have used hot air brushes for probably close to 20 years. But this is my first John Frieda. Really really wish I had discovered this brand from the beginning. It is far above and beyond the best I've ever used. I'm not sure what is different about this one, but my hair looks worlds better and it's much easier and quicker with this brush. I usually shower before I sleep and go to bed with my hair wet. I'll wake up with my hair going crazy in 100 different directions. It only takes me minutes to style with this brush. Absolutely love it.
  5. Does not get that hot .....
  6. One of the best purchases I have ever made
  7. Absolutely love this! Makes styling my hair easier and comes out beautifully!
  8. Smooths hair like a flat iron but without the damage!
  9. Not very powerful but it does help smooth your hair after you have gotten pretty much all of the moisture out.
  10. Nice unit but the handle was a little too large for my wife,s hand so I returned it for credit.
  11. I've been trying to find a decent hot air brush for ages, and they all have disappointed me - that is until I bought this one.<br /><br />This works so much better than the round brush + blow dryer combo when you are trying to give yourself a blow out. If this is any help - here are some tips I picked up from another person using a hot air brush - first I let my hair air dry for 15-20 min, then use a bit of the Bumble and Bumble Thickening Spray (just on roots) or Paul Mitchell Thicken Up, then I part my hair just under the ears and clip it up on to of my head and blow out that lower area, then (with my fingers) section my hair at about the temple point, clip that up, then go around and blow out that level, then just finish with the top, starting at the back of your head and finishing with the very front. You can hold it rolled up longer to create a flip going up or a flip going under - when you do that after having it on the warm setting, switch it to cool to set the wave.<br /><br />Anyway, this is a great brush and I love using it every time I want to blow out my fine, curly hair.
  12. I really like this hot air brush. I'm not so coordinated with using a hair dryer and round brush, so this is perfect for me. I can get a blowout that looks like I've been to the hair salon. I usually blow my hair about 3/4 dry with a regular hair dryer and then use this brush. I use on high and it doesn't get too hot. Also, it does not tangle like another smaller heated curling brush that I once had. Hair seems to glide through this brush. Takes just a little practice and in no time you are a pro with this hair styling tool. Highly recommend. Great tool for the price too!!
  13. Love this but it seemed to loose some of its blowing power after just a few uses
  14. This hot air brush is as amazing as the other reviewers have declared it to be! The first time I used it I got absolutely stunning results, SALON blow-out results, actually. Just make sure your hair is 95% dry. This is my new best friend. I agree with other reviewers, it would be nice if the switch from hot to cold was a little easier to work with. It just takes a micro movement to move from one to the other...which is a little awkward. But that is the only minor complaint I have. My hair didn't get tangled at all...
  15. Dries well, brush not so bad, but it does not leave my hair silky like this other dryer brush I had which had aluminum like bristles. This one leaves it a little frizzy so I have to go over it with an iron.
  16. I have straight, fine, medium length hair and this is awesome. It takes me 10-15 min to blow it out and it looks like I walked out of a salon!
  17. Makes your hair perfect. Removes all friz and flyaway.
  18. You are unable to clean easily. Can't was in water.
  19. Even though it wasn't that expensive, due to other's reviews, I thought this would work a little better. I have thin hair, so I expected better results...but this brush did NOTHING for me. Useless.
  20. This product is very easy to use even for hair dummies like me. My hair looks like it does when I leave the salon. Just make sure that your hair is not too wet when you use it or the style will not take.
  21. I have very curly hair, this product its probably best for fine - thin hair. And the bristles are very soft.
  22. I got this John Frieda hot air brush as an early Christmas present for myself mainly to dry my hair because I have problems with frizz if I use a regular hair dryer so I figured I would try this hot air brush instead and it has enough heat that comes from it to dry well enough I believe but it does not create unwanted frizz and it actually gives me a little more volume to my hair but I have thick, curly hair so it usually has enough volume in it but I could still tell the difference after using this hot air brush. This product seems to be a high quality product because it has a louder sound when turned on than I was expecting but at least I can tell it will work good. This hot brush sounds like a regular hair dryer to me and maybe a little louder but it is not too loud and not unbearable to stand. I am considering purchasing a few more of these as presents for other people in the future because I think this product would work well for any woman that wants dry and styled hair without the frizz.

  28. I have had a number of hot brushes and hair dryer brushes, thinking they couldn't be that different! I am here to tell you they are different. This hot air brush is GREAT! I have thin hair and tends to be frizzy. I have tried different &#34;no frizz&#34; oils and potions and nothing worked consistently. I thought maybe I should not blow dry my hair...that didn't work well either. Then I read reviews on this John Frieda Salon Shape 1.5 inch Hot Air Brush and thought the advanced ionic technology sounded intriguing. There is 3 temp settings. Well I absolutely love this product. I have gotten complements on my hair looking healthy from my husband and others. It smoothes out the hair with no frizzies and gives it body. I highly recommend.
  29. Makes my hair straight or wavy I love it
  30. I have used hot air brushes for years and have usually just gone to the local Wal-Mart or something when I have needed a new one. This time I took my time and did research. This John Frieda brush came out at the top of most of the reviews that I looked into, unfortunately it wasn't available in any of my local stores so I turned to Amazon as the price was reasonable and it seemed that the reviews were favorable here too. Within the first couple of times I used it, I had great results. It is very easy to use and not awkward to handle. My hair doesn't get tangled in it as others have done in the past. I love it. Hopefully this one will last longer then others I have purchased, but I would definitely buy another if I had to. I would recommend it.
  31. This design is the best I've seen in this type of dryer and I've had many of them. It's shorter than most of this type of dryer, so is easy to hold on to and move around. However, for me, it didn't seem to be hot enough. But it did heat up quickly and may be sufficient for you...I am just into high heat dryers moreso. Also, I have thin hair and the barrell is too big so all it did was straighten my hair more than it already is. It DID dry it nicely. Also, the design is a good one because it doesn't have open \\"vents\\" at end of handle. My long hair has gotten caught in those. I am pretty sure if the barrell was smaller (I thought the size would be OK), I would've kept this. It's more pro feeling than the others I've had. Give it a try b/c the design is just so good and manageable. This could be your best dryer if you can use a two inch barrell. I always dry my hair about halfway (or air dry it) before using this type of brush dryer, tho that isn't necessary for all users. I just think it makes drying/styling go faster. I use mousse on wet hair and then when ready to brush dry, I use a light styling spray. LIGHT, not hair spray or you will have nothing but stiff hair and the brush will protest!
  32. I have thick curly hair, it's also pretty long. I usually let it dry naturally but that takes all damn day. I like the look when I round brush but that takes at least an hour. So I got this thing thinking I would save some time. Just like when I round brush my hair, I wait til my hair is damp or almost dry. The tutorials on youtube make this look so easy as it glides through your hair. It doesn't. At least it didn't on me. I still had to section off my hair and just do little pieces at time....which still took an hour.<br /><br />Maybe if it had a thicker barrel? I have the biggest round brush they make and it glides through my hair, but this kept getting stuck. It only works with very small sections at a time. Probably works well on short hair also. It was a failed experiment. I'm going to give it to my sister who has short thin hair, I'm sure it will work for her.

  38. I give this item 5 stars because it meets all the criteria I was looking for. It was the best price, it came with Amazon free shipping and it does exactly what I bought it for. I have thin natural curly (frizzy) hair. This Hot Air Brush along with some leave in hair products made my thin frizzy hair smooth and much more manageable. I use it to style after first taking out the moisture with my blow dryer for about 2 minutes. I also use it the next day as more of a shaper and styler. Like a hot roller with or without the curl.<br /><br />It takes a little getting use to but once you do it's very easy. I will be buying one for my daughter who has curlier hair than I do.   39. There are a few misfires with this product. First off, it does not produce enough air to dry normal or thicker hair. You need to air dry or dry your hair with a conventional hairdryer before styling with this brush. Also, the placement of the temperature lever is awkward and requires that you remove the brush and reset the temp. A larger barrel would also be nice. It does, however, not get stuck in your hair when using it and that is a plus. Overall it will do the job if you have thin hair & patience.
  40. I absolutely love this hot air brush. I have not used my blow dryer at all since receiving this. It leaves my hair soft, and beautifully styled with just enough lift and wave. I was very skeptical about whether this product would even work for me, I was wrong....I couldn't be happier with the results.

The bristles on this air brush are a soft rubber so they do not tug and rip at hair.   59. I've had this product for a while now, I've not found another product like it on the net. It's drying power is very good, but don't expect it to blast your hair dry. The hot setting is plenty hot to dry your hair quickly. By pushing the button all the way up you can change to a cool air blast to &#34;set&#34; a large curl. My hair is thin and fine, so takes no time to dry. If your hair is long and thick, I would imagine that it would require considerable time to dry if you only used this product. Likely you would use another dryer to pre dry to a point and then use this one with the ionization ability to finish. Leaves my hair soft but not frizzy. Appears to be very durable and the no tangle cord is a plus. The bristles never catch or pull my hair and I have absolutely no problem using this product. Worth the money.

I have very fine, thin, silky hair that tangles very easily and this never does. it adds tremendous body, shine, volume, and CURL to my hair.

I even tried it when my hair was completely dry to see if I could just use it to &#34;polish&#34; my look and it did not give me a smooth even look like I was hoping for. I won't switch to this from using a nozzle blow dryer and ceramic round brush. Now, I'm a stylist. I desire results many don't.   72. I have naturally curly hair but it is fine and needs humidity for the curl to look it's best. I hate the time it takes to blow dry my hair straight with a round brush. When I saw this product I thought there is no way this styling brush could actually work. Let me tell you - it does really work. My stylist suggested I wash my hair at night and put a straightening creme in it after it's towel dried. I go to bed with it wet and wake up with my hair 95% dry. I spritz in some leave in conditioner and add a small amount of heat protectant straightening creme, then use the air brush. I section my shoulder length hair, styling one section at a time, making it easier to manage. It literally takes 10 minutes for all this! The first time I used it I got so many compliments and one of my coworkers went out that very afternoon to buy a styling brush! I watched the video one reviewer put on here and watched other YouTube tutorials. Yes, the dryer part of the brush isn't very forceful, but it is definitely hot. I gingerly hold the end of the brush as I am using it. Totally love that this cuts my styling time in half. I wish I had discovered this product years ago. You will not be disappointed! If you are unsure about buying it online, Ulta Cosmetic stores carry it and with a coupon it ends up being the same price.
  73. My hair used to be curly and I never had to use a dryer of any kind. If I wore it curly all I had to do was wash and let it dry naturally. When I wanted a straighter look I followed the \\"Spanish\\" method. It takes a long time to dry but the results are wonderful. Over time my hair has straightened somewhat and I still use the \\"Spanish\\" method but when I haven't time I use the John Frieda JFHA5 Hot Air Brush. I really like it. My hair is shiny and smooth when finished and the brush is very gentle on my hair. The \\"Spanish\\" method: Wash hair as usual, take a large amount of hair from the crown of one's head and comb it straight and roll it over the largest roller you can buy, clip it in place. All the remaining hair is then combed around your head until smooth (head is acting as a huge roller), clip in place, cover with a sturdy hair net and sleep on it. You will be delighted with the results but you do need time for it to dry.
  74. I was out shopping for a brush that I can use to freshen up my hair without having to blow it out. And this is the brush.<br />Not only is it NOT Damaging, but gives you volume and shine. And it is light enough to carry on short trips.<br />Love it!!! Plus you can use it everyday!
  75. The perfect temperature and the best bristles--soft and smooth touch on the scalp!! Finally a well designed and efficient hot hair brush (John Frieda JFHA5 Hot Air Brush) that neither burn your scalp nor damage your hair.
  76. I have thick, wavy Asian hair that gets big with any humidity. Only the Brazilian blowout has helped control the volume in my hair. Not wanting to undergo the chemical exposure I wanted to find another method to tame my hair. Flat-ironing is extremely damaging to my hair, but I needed something with heat to smooth the cuticle. I have a hard time blowing out my hair using a brush and a blow dryer, so my hair dresser suggested I try a hot air brush. The John Frieda hot air brush straightens my hair and overall I'm glad I purchased it. There are, however, significant flaws:<br /><br />-The base should have some sort of textured grip. When using styling products in trying to style my hair, my hands get slippery and it's difficult to get a firm grip sometimes. I've dropped it a few times, but fortunately it's still working.<br /><br />-The controls are difficult to slide. You cannot use one hand to change from low to high or to cool. This is the most severe design flaw. It is extremely difficult to give your hair a blast a cool air to set it using only one hand while you're in the middle of styling your hair. If it weren't for this I would have rated this air brush higher.<br /><br />If this one breaks down, I would think twice before I would purchase it again for these reasons.
  77. I will never go back to a regular blow dryer again! My hair is thick, coarse and wavy and very stubborn. This tames my frizz and leaves my hair amazingly soft. The only tip I've learner is this is best to use on semi-dry hair, not soaking wet and heavy. It flattened the bristles.<br />Love it!
  78. good value for money!!
  79. Bought this Hot Air Brush for my daughter but think I have used it more. It is very easy to use with great results.
  80. This product has made a huge difference in my hair. I have extremely fine, but curly hair and I usually dry it every morning with a round brush and a regular blow dryer. The result is often frizzy and dry looking but I needed to do this to get volume and to pull out the curls.<br /><br />Now I use this dryer every morning and my hair is shiny, bouncy and healthy looking and the frizz is almost completely gone. It is a great product and I love it. Doesn't feel like it is damaging my hair either! It does take a little longer to dry so I usually just blow with my old dryer a bit first, and then switch to this, but that works just fine.<br /><br />Also, at the end of the day if my hair is messy or has been ruined by the weather, it only takes a minute to fix it again using this dryer.   86. I have used this brush for a few weeks. The size of the handle provides a good grip. The brush gripes the hair firmly but does not get tangled. I would prefer that the brush was a inch longer. I dislike the brush because the control switch is so tight that I can not turn the brush on with my finger (i.e. push down and push up). Instead I need to use my finger nail to wedge under the bottom of the switch and push the switch to the on position. Once turned &#34;on&#34; I can move the switch to one of the optional settings. I have repeatedly moved the switch trying to &#34;break it in&#34; with no success. If the control switch was easier to use I would give this brush a rating of 4 stars.
  87. Blowdrying my hair can take an hour with a traditional blow dryer and brush, hence I never did it. I figured I would try again and that's when I found this one. I like that the bristles are both &#34;natural&#34; and plastic. It holds the hair well without tangling and leaves hair shiny. It's lightweight and just hot enough. I am still surprised at how easy it is to use and the results are great! I do recommend using when hair is partly dry and for this I still use my blowdryer. Overall, couldn't be happier.

  100. I just got this the other day. In the instructions it says to get your hair to about 80% dry before using this. So I had to blow it dry for awhile, mostly at the roots, then I started with this. It is pretty cool. It saves having to use two hands and your arms all up in the air for the whole time you have to dry you hair, which for me is at least a half an hour. I have waist length slightly layered hair that dries to slightly wavy. As it dries normally it goes through a super frizzy looking stage. Because it takes so long to dry, I usually let it air dry. If I wanted to blow it straight at home it would take forever and just be too much. I liked this because it has hot low speed, hot high speed and then cool high speed. It really gave me that blown out look with a lot less effort. When I wanted to put a bit of a curl on it, I could blow it at hot then cool it off and then take it out of the hair. It cut the time down and looked like I spent a lot longer. I am going to have to work on it getting to curl more and maybe use some heat safe hair product. It gets hot. It has the soft and harder brush teeth on it, so its like two brushes and a dryer in one. I really like it. My hair is really soft, super nice feeling with a lot less effort. It's as close as I have gotten to the fresh from the salon feel on my own. The brush dryer itself seems pretty sturdy, and easy to use and access the control switch as you are using it. The shape makes it like you are just brushing your hair. Easy to use.

  111. Great idea...just not perfect. Pros: good idea, bristles hold the hair well, and low and high setting. Cons: only 500 watts (my normal hairdryer is 2100 watts), takes FOREVER TO DRY YOUR HAIR, no cool touch tip at the end so if you touch the end of the roller, OUCH, you will get burned. So all in all not a horrible product, just not good either. I got great volume out of but with low power like 500 Watts you'll spend way more time doing your hair than you will showing it off. This product might work on very short Halle Berry length hair, but anything past your ears, prepare to add some extra time to your schedule (+30 to 1 hr extra) to use this. I have a lot of fine but curly hair a little past my shoulders and normal drying time is 30 minutes for me and another 10 minutes if I touch it up with the flat iron. Using this product it took 1 hr and 15 minutes to dry and curl it, but my hair wasn't as straight as when you blow dry it with a roller brush. I still had kinks in it. I tried to use the flat iron after to touch it up but my roots were still somewhat curly and weird. Not a good look. I ended up buying the Revlon titanium hot air styler with 1200 watts instead and wow what a difference. Now I've got a couple of improvements for Revlon too, it's not perfect either, but certainly deserves more stars than John Frieda simply due to the huge increase in power which makes a huge difference.

Another disadvantage is that you can't remove the brush to clean or wash it - not good. I am Caucasian but as I have gotten older my hair has gotten curlier and frizzier. I just turned 65 and it was getting so unruly.) Using this was like putting in a large hot roller but with a handle and running it through my hair to the end and then I just turned the barrel a bit until it caught the ends and began rolling upwards, catching all the hair in it as though it was a roller. i held it there a very short time (should have done longer to give it a little more curl on ends but I didn't have time so went with the straight look) and unrolled it. i did it in huge chunks of hair and it only took 14 minutes to go through all my hair like that. it held throughout the day well too. no frizz at end of day. when the straightener wears off i think I could still use this product to quickly straighten and de-frizz it a bit at end of day if we are going out that night. I have problem hair and nothing can change that, but this is a huge help! I love the big barrel also to hold onto it. little handles are hard to hold for very long!

  143. I had my doubts when reading the descriptions of this product online at amazon and elsewhere. It just seemed that it really wasn't clear what this \\"hot air\\" brush would do (increase volume, shine. Hmm. OK.). Should have heeded my instincts.<br /><br />Read the reviews before ordering so I was aware that given its low wattage this is not meant to be used as a \\"real\\" dryer if you have long and/or thick hair. So I wasn't expecting this to function as a dryer on my long (collar), medium-thick wet hair.<br /><br />But I did expect that I could straighten and style damp hair given its description as a \\"hot air\\" brush. However, this hot air brush didn't do much of anything for my hair--definitely no volume and no shine. Took several minutes (a lot longer than using regular hair dryer and brush!) to get small sections of hair straight and dry and though my hair is easily styled/set with curling irons, this brush did not add any body or shape. VERY disappointing.<br /><br />About the only thing it is good for? Spot drying and straightening damp sections of hair at nape, neckline, etc. after a shower or bath before then going on to actually style hair with electric rollers and/or curling iron. At this price, that's an expensive product option since one could easily do the same with any cheap hair dryer and a brush.<br /><br />My hair is wavy rather than tight curly but I found that this brush was not very effective in straightening hair or adding \\"body\\" though I tried it on hair that was different degrees of damp. (And yes, I followed the instructions, which suggest that you use when your hair is \\"80% dry\\" and I did turn my hair upside down and blow/brush out from the roots.)<br /><br />As for making my hair less static? Could not discern any noticeable difference.<br /><br />Only seeming plus: It did not seem to dry hair out as much as when using a traditional hair dryer and brush.<br /><br />Having used it quite a bit in initial two weeks I did not feel comfortable returning it, but I wish I had. Total waste of money.<br /><br />Given some of the other newer comments, it seems that no matter what length your hair is, others have experienced similar problems and disappointment.<br /><br />To the folks at John Frieda hair care products, I hope you read these comments and do something to improve the product. I love your actual hair care products and use them daily so my expectation level for the performance of this product was high based on prior positive experience.newer comments, it seems that no matter what length your hair is, others have experienced similar problems and disappointment. To the folks at John Frieda hair care products, I hope you read these comments and do something to improve the product. I love your actual hair care products and use them daily so my expectation level for the performance of this product was high based on prior positive experience.
  144. My Wigo hot air brush has given up the ghost, and doesn't seem to be carried by anyone any longer. I searched for possible alternatives for my shoulder length defiantly STRAIGHT layered hair, and found the same old products, which I have tried and am not impressed with. Instead, I found this new hot air brush by John Frieda, and it is WONDERFUL. I received it 3 days ago, and I am truly enjoying using it. The picture doesn't really show this, but it has two types of bristles; one is longer, stiffer and has rounded ends, and a short set of normal softer bristles. This brush head really grabs my hair and guides it around the brush - no more slithering out of the brush head, and burned fingers from trying to guide my hair around the brush. It doesn't tangle my hair, releases easily, and I am not ending up with any fuzzy, kinked ends from not having wrapped my hair around the brush properly before setting the curl. The high heat setting isn't too hot, so it doesn't burn my scalp, and it has a cool setting (that is a little bit hard to find) that helps set the curl. It does have a little seam in the housing that caught my hair initially and pulled out a few hairs - I think I might seal that with epoxy, and I would love it if this brush came in a 1 1/4 inch barrel size. My hair looks like my hairdresser blow dried it after using this product - even in the back - and the curl and body last all day!! I am buying another as a spare/travel hot air brush.
  145. I bought the John Frieda Hot Air Brush after I already had the similar 2\\" Conair rotating brush. I'll make this simple, if you are comparing these 2 for a purchase:<br /><br />1) Both are good quality and are similar in style and girth. Both are wide and can be cumbersome to hold, especially if you have small hands. With that said, Conair's dryer is easier because it spins and hair easily attaches to the barrel. Note: it can tangle the hair if too much is caught.<br />2) I do not use either to physically dry my hair, only style. I blow-dry my hair to 90% dry with a traditional dryer first. Using this product to dry your hair (unless it was short or very fine) would take a ridiculous amount of time to dry. Don't waste your time unless this is the only dryer you have and you're in a \\"hurry\\"... otherwise, wait for it to air-dry or use a traditional hair dryer.<br />3) The Conair rotates which creates a tremendously smooth finish with minimal effort since it does the majority of the work.<br />4) John F.'s 1.5\\" barrel size is perfect for my top layers (my hair is long with shorter layers on top) and using it I can create incredible volume at the root, almost magical.<br />5) John F.'s cool setting is much better than Conair's which I can barely detect. Note: Conair's product will not spin in the cool setting, which is a bummer IMO.<br /><br />Bottom line, if John F.'s product had the ability to spin, it would be my go-to choice, hands down. John F, please enhance this dryer so it spins, then it's a total win!

I highly recommend blow drying your hair 80% dry on low setting with a standard dryer first and then use this dryer to style, smooth, and curl. I also use it at the root to give some lift, just be sure to keep the dryer at the roots and lift and this will give lots of movement to your hair.
  160. This is a good styler to finish off my hair style. I usually use my regular blow dryer and round brush and get my hair about 80 percent dry, then add body and smoothness with the hot air brush. Makes my hair look professionally blown out, and I can go a little longer between haircuts. Highly recommended.
  161. This does a much better job than the rotating brush I bought a few weeks ago. I recommend it<br />to anyone who has short to medium-length hair. It adds volume and shape. I touch it up with<br />an iron right after blowing dry, but this would be optional. Decent value.
  162. I have lots of fine hair, shoulder length, and this is perfect. I used to blow dry with a round brush then curl it with a curling iron. This does everything in one step and my hair looks so shiny and so much better than before! It is also lightweight and the bristles are soft but catch my flyaway hair with no problem. I like the small size of it too, nice for travel. I also purchased the Conair SD4P Unisex Hair 1875-Watt Styler with Three Attachments, this was way too hot for my hair and scalp. The John Frieda hot air brush has the perfect heat for fine hair. Probably would need to blowdry a little first if you have super thick hair or usually need a high heat dryer.

  185. Although I spend quite a while doing my makeup most days, my frizzy, fine, semi-wavy hair has led to years and years of letting it air-dry and then pulling it back with a clip or ponytail holder to just get it the heck out of the way. Enter this hot air brush. I have had this product for a few weeks now, and I use it every morning and *love* it! It dries and styles my hair simultaneously and does so fairly quickly. I can now dry and style my hair with just one hand as I build great volume and lift and get great smooth flips incredibly easily. The bristles in addition to the plastic prongs mean the dryer grabs and actually holds on to my hair, whereas I typically need to hold my hair on as I use a styler.<br /><br />The few things I would change would be the button and the tip. The slider button works just fine, but I think a button might be easier as you transition from heat to cool, to set the gentle curls. When drying the back of my head, I often reach to stabilize the styler and keep it level, so I can tell you that the tip gets very hot! I am sure there is a reason they made it with the material they did, but I would like to see them coat it with a material that remains cool to the touch. It would also be great if the cord retracted, though I fear they would need to make the barrel larger for this.<br /><br />I cannot recommend this product highly enough to those who are looking for a product that will dry their hair as it adds volume and body. I love it and, when it inevitably wears out some day, I will most definitely be purchasing another.
  186. I am new to the world of hot air brushes and I am very happy so far. Styling with this brush takes longer than my powerful blow dryer, but I like the end result. My hair comes out smoother and the layers show more definition and movement - just like they do when my stylist blows it dry. I am not sure I will be able to spend the time to use this brush every day, but it is great to have another \\"look\\" to achieve on the days I want/need to put in the time! It even worked on the back of my head, which is an area I have not devoted much concern to in the past! I do wish it had more power. Also, the way the sliding control button is designed makes it hard for me to use. If you slide it all the way to the end it goes to a \\"cool\\" setting rather than the highest, hottest setting. That setting is one notch back and it is difficult to get it to slide back just that little notch to get the high hot setting.

  188. I bought this back in December 2011 and at first I really didn't like it. I used it in place of my regular hair dryer and my hair was very frizzy and still slightly damp after about 20 minutes with this. I ended up needing my regular hair dryer and flat iron to finish the job. I tried it to finish my hair after using my regular hair drier and I still didn't love it. So in the drawer and out of sight it went. Several months to a year later, I pulled it out again and started trying different ways to use it. I have super thick hair this is currently medium length and it loves to frizz a lot. I didn't used to dry my hair daily because it was a 45 minute process and involved a couple of hair products and a hair dryer and flat iron to make it look great. My hair is naturally super curly and takes a long time to dry. Normally I'd just put a little style cream in my hair, tie it back in a ponytail and go. Not the cutest look but necessary since I wasn't willing to give up that much sleep.<br /><br />Now I style my hair every day and it only takes me 15 minutes with this little gem. I towel dry my hair for a minute or two, comb it out and put a dime size amount of Sebastian Potion 9 in it. I let it air dry for about 2 to 3 minutes while I get ready and then start with this hot air brush. I take small sections of my hair and slide the hair brush down a section starting from the scalp. I run it down the section 2 to 3 times and then I roll my hair around the brush starting with the tips of my hair. I roll it up to the scalp and wait about 5 seconds. I slide the brush out and start on another section. Once I have finished going around all the sections, I take a larger section and run this brush through it rolling from the bottom. Once I'm happy with my hair, I put a dab (smaller than dime size) of Fekkai glossing cream in my hair and run it through my hair. My hair holds the style for a couple of days and looks very shiny and feels amazingly soft. I can't believe I let this sit in my drawer unused for almost a year. I use it 4 to 5 times a week now and it's still going strong. This also makes traveling a lot easier since now I'm not packing a separate brush, hair dryer and flat iron. I'll be getting a second one soon in case something happens to this one.<br /><br />When I first used this, I realized that I was trying to dry too much hair at once. It works best when you can do small sections so it can properly dry the hair completely. I don't know if it works better than other brands since this is the only one I've used but this works amazing well and I couldn't be happier with it.lieve I let this sit in my drawer unused for almost a year. I use it 4 to 5 times a week now and it's still going strong. This also makes traveling a lot easier since now I'm not packing a separate brush, hair dryer and flat iron. I'll be getting a second one soon in case something happens to this one.<br /><br />When I first used this, I realized that I was trying to dry too much hair at once. It works best when you can do small sections so it can properly dry the hair completely. I don't know if it works better than other brands since this is the only one I've used but this works amazing well and I couldn't be happier with it.

  196. I have shoulder-length, layered, fine textured hair and this product is great for lift and body, especially on the top and crown. I let my hair air-dry about 75 percent before using this hot air brush and it works great. I would have to believe that it can be cumbersome and tiresome trying to dry longer, thicker or wetter hair because the wattage is lower than that of a blow dryer.<br /><br />I also see a lot of reviews criticizing the power/strength of the air flow. This is done for your safety -- the dryer cannot be stronger (as it is with an external blow dryer) because the heat is applied directly to the hair. A higher wattage would irreparably damage the hair and likely burn your scalp as well.<br /><br />I would recommend this anyone with hair similar to mine and to those who need/want more lift on the top of the head.
  197. My hair is wavy/curly-ish/frizzy, medium thickness and I love the way my hair comes out after using this hot air brush.<br /><br />The only downside to this brush for me is that I have to let my hair dry naturally (I use a super-absorbent hair towel) for a long time, over 30 minutes, before I use the Hot Air Brush. Otherwise, it won't really dry well, but if I do wait the time and use this brush when my hair is slightly dried, it comes out beautiful, no frizz and with a lot of body, just like when you get it blown out at a salon! I don't know what would make this product better other than maybe a stronger heat or more powerful, but I don't mind letting my hair dry a bit before using this. Love it!

  207. I've used another brand for years but it fails right after the 12-mo warranty so you have to buy a new one each year. This has a longer warranty so I thought I'd try it, even though it does cost considerably more than what I was used to. It does dry and shape the hair well enough.<br /><br />My two main complaints are:<br /><br />1) that the brush head is not removable for cleaning.<br />2) the grey endcap by the brush is so short you cannot hold onto it to guide and control the brush. It will burn your fingers if used in hot mode.<br /><br />It is recommended that you wipe it down with a wet cloth but that doesn't do the trick. After a few weeks of use with any type of styling spray, it gets gunky. I have to lift any excess hair off with a comb, then immerse the brush end into hot water, letting it sit there a bit before I can brush off the bristles with an old tooth brush to get the gunk off of it. I then towel dry it very well and am careful not to let any water near the handle part that has the electrical stuff inside.<br /><br /> Because the brush-head has bristles like a brush, as opposed to stationery hard plastic bristles, it is not very easy to clean, whereas my former styler did come apart and I found it easy to set it in a deep tumbler of warm water overnight and wipe off the next morning :)

  210. At my last trip to the salon, I got bangs. I haven't had bangs since I was 10. I have long, straight and very fine hair. I needed a change but a playful pixie or a long bob weren't options based on my hair type. Bangs seemed like a good alternative for a dramatic statement. I felt great about the cut when I left the salon but fretted recreating the look on my own. I can't hold a blow dryer and opperate a round brush at the same time. I researched hot air brushed and stumbled upon this one.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Very easy to use. With a round brush, I am constantly working my hair into knots. I've been using this for months and have yet to tangle.<br />- High, low, and cool heat settings. I typically use the high heat setting to dry my hair and then the low to style my bangs.<br />- Salon-look shine. Being able to dry my hair piece by piece gives me that volume and body that I get after a cut at the salon.<br />- 1.5'' brush. Curls and styles my bangs without making them 80's big.<br />- No need to use straightener. Unless you're looking for stick straight, this tool can replace the blow dryer and the straight iron. Some days I blow dry with the regular dryer and then use this tool to straighten.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- It takes a while. My straight, thin hair takes no time to dry with the blow dryer. This takes much longer. If you really want the styled look, you have to use clips and dry piece by piece.<br />- Does not have a moveable cord like some of the others in this category<br /><br />All in all, I highly recommend. The pros significantly outweigh the cons. This is a perfect tool for long, straight, fine hair.

I let it dry about 80% and used a light hair oil on my ends. I love my curly hair but as a every day hair style it drove me crazy because i could never get the shape i wanted to and my curls just did what they wanted. I am anti flat iron after using one for so many years and finally growing out my hair so it can be healthy and wanted something for my hair that wouldnt cause a lot of damage. This hot air brush is amazing, it made me look as if i just walked out of the salon the first time i used it, it was so easy. Also wanted to add i bought the Conair h ot air brush to try it out and it was horrible it didnt work for me. The spin function got my hair caught in the brush and the worst part the metal got so hot it burnt my finger. This one doesnt get hot like the conair one. This really has really helped me so much because not only is it fast but i am so happy with the way my hair looks now!<br /><br />Pros:<br />Easy to use<br />Transforms your hair<br />Quiet<br />Eliminates frizz<br /><br />Cons:<br />I didnt get this sooner<br /><br />*If you dont want to crush the bristles when you store it they sell plastic covers at beauty supply stores
  240. Returning this product. Since the hair blows out from the brush, it forced all my fly aways out and made my hair look much worse! Awful concept, not sure why it has so many great reviews, perhaps its just not great for fine hair?
  241. 3 months later and it's dead. Proceed with caution.
  242. love it, easy to carry and makes life so much easier with brush and blow dryer in one. Wont recommend this product to those with thick and heavy hair
  243. It is a styler and if you are expecting it to dry your hair then you are on the wrong track like me. And you can't take the brush off another con for me. I had to buy a separate blow dryer. Not really happy with it.

Waiting to hear back from the company on the warranty for this product. Update 3/6/17: It wasn't the motor that was dying, my cord was acting up. It stays on my counter and I don't wrap the cord up so not sure why except for just by using it. It finally died completely this morning- 2 years after I purchased it. I did purchase another as it really does work better than ones I've had in the past.

  254. It does exactly what I was expecting. I'm more than happy with this. I bought this product for my mom she is not able to straighten her hair by herself, she always complained about her arms and neck getting to tired every time she used a flat iron, or a blower, even the in styler she said to be afraid to burn herself with it. So I always had to blow dry her hair for like an hour (not an easy job). She tried this out yesterday and her hair looks so beautiful, soft, with texture and she looked so happy amd proud of herself because she could do it on her own, I was shocked.. maybe this sounds silly but I felt this was the best purchase I've ever done.   255. It normally takes me 45 minutes to do a good blowout on my long, layered, thick hair. Being a new mom, I can't spend this much time on my hair. This air brush is awesome for giving a salon-quality blowout that really lasts. The bristles help you get good tension in the hair and the barrel diameter is perfect. The air brush is really lightweight, so your arm won't get sore like it would with a blowdryer. A few tips:<br /><br />- For thicker hair, it won't cut your styling time in half, though it will still reduce it. I've found that I need to rough dry my hair with the blowdryer until it's 90% dry, then use the air brush while sectioning the hair (exactly how you'd do it with a round brush and dryer).<br />- To really get the top layers smooth, I use the brush over and under the hair.<br />- I take my time to do a good blowout once a week, and then use the air brush for a quick refresh every morning afterwards.<br />- To clean the brush, I just run a comb through the bristles after every use.<br />- It may seem like the air isn't hot enough, but I think the lower heat is actually better for your hair. It still straightens my hair but hasn't caused any breakage so far.<br />- You still need to manually rotate the brush to smooth hair, but I don't see this as a con - I would never want to risk using one of those rotating brushes that the hair could get all tangled up in.<br />- You can get really close to the roots and won't burn your scalp, which helps get that amazing bounce and body you get from a salon blowout.<br /><br />I would guess that this could be a perfect tool for those with fine hair. For those with thicker hair, it's great, but still requires a good amount of work to use. Still, it makes the process much easier!
  256. This brush is so easy to use, it's very lightweight. It's also very powerful for such a small brush. I can dry my hair in half the time as I did before.
  257. Probably one of the best hair care investments I've ever made. It not only saves time but money. It has already paid for itself!!
  258. I have great coordination for most things but not for holding a blow dryer and brush and actually twisting and turning the brush at the same time so THIS has been a lifesaver and major time SAVER for me. I have tried a few of the Conair versions and they tend to get hot and burn me on the brush area or they have not lasted. But neither of the Conair ones have produced the affect that is like what you get at the salon with the dryer and a round brush. The John Frieda does!!!! The only downside is that it takes a long time to dry from very wet hair. But I cut the time by blow drying my hair with my regular hair dryer and once it's damp, I finish up with this. It doesn't blow loose strands of hair all over the place while it's working. Some other brands I have tried have air coming out in the middle and they do that. Then I am left with all kinds of frizzy strands sticking up all over the place. I just can't say enough about this little gem of a find. The one downside I found was that the on/off switch is a little hard to use. But I have gotten used to it and it's not a big deal at all anymore. I hope they never stop making it because it's awesome.

  270. The first time I used this hot air brush, I didn't like it. It left my hair flat and lifeless. I was ready to send it back when I thought I'd give it one more try. Boy, was I glad I did. I have past my shoulder- length hair. I blow dry my hair with a regular blow dryer with my hair flipped upside down to give it volume. Next I use the air brush, section by section. I start at the roots of one section and work my way down to the ends, first using hot for 10 seconds and then switching to cool to set in the lift. It leaves my fine hair full and shiny. The great thing about it is that you do not have to use a round brush with a blow dryer. Because it's an all-in-one tool, it is so easy to handle. I highly recommend this product.

  274. After reading most of the reviews, I thought I better give the Hot Air Brush a try. The blow dryer part is not very powerful. I have thick, course, wavy, long (to the middle of my back) hair that needs heat to take out most of the frizz. This is not a miracle worker. I still have to almost totally blow dry my hair with my blow dryer. Once it's mostly dry, I use the Hot Air Brush to build in body, but I still have to use my other blow dryer on top of it to get enough heat and drying action (and my flat iron to work out some of my curl). I was hoping this Air Brush would help to take a step out of my morning routine- this doesn't seem to be the case. For those with smooth, lovely hair already, this may be the ticket to build in long lasting body. My mom has short hair and she loved it, the Hot Air Brush gave her body and dried her hair. For $30, it was worth a try! I think I'll be giving this to my mom.

  330. I bought this thing on a whim after my stylist had told me one of her clients had been happy with the \\"Instyler\\" product. After my review reading self checked it out on amazon, I decided it was overpriced and I probably wouldn't be happy with it. Somehow I came across this gem and I couldn't be happier!<br /><br />Here is some background about myself and hair:<br /><br />I have no versatility or coordination when it comes to styling my hair.<br />New mom looking for something to help me look put together since drying/straightening was often too much of a production.<br />Shoulder length thick/fine hair (if that even makes sense)<br />Filled with random cowlicks and uneven waves/curls/straight areas<br />Retains moisture like you wouldn't believe.<br /><br />I typically did the hair dryer thing and followed with a Chi straightener. I had noticed over the past few years my hair started resembling a bad hair commercial. It looked fine, but due to the fact it retained moisture, I was never patient enough to get it COMPLETELY dry with the hair dryer. Oh, and that entire thing with a round brush/hair dryer, never worked for me. In the early 2000's I used hot rollers and my hair always looked flawless. Then one day it started looking 'dated' and I switched to the straightening. Now when I try hot rollers, it just doesn't look right anymore because of the damage from the straightener.<br /><br />I was skeptical to use this product because I just didn't know if it would get my hair dry enough. To my surprise, it did! It does take some time, but probably about 5 minutes more than drying/straightening. That 5 minutes is so worth the final product of my hair. My hair looks styled and is smooth. Sometimes it doesn't quite get the cowlicks out. That's probably due to more laziness on my part and not using the right products. I have found that winding sections all the way to the root of my hair and letting it sit there for a few minutes gives me the best results and gets it the driest. Most of the time this product forces me to address all sections of my hair to ensure they are dry and straight. I constantly missed areas with my old routine.<br /><br />I am only giving it 4 stars because I do feel like it could have a bit more power. However, this has proven to be way less damaging on my hair than my old routine of drying/straightening. I'm not sure if an increase of power would cause damage or not.
  331. It's east to use, at first you find you think it is not working, because the bristles seem to not grab your hair, I use it in conjunction with a hair dryer, it takes no time to get ready!   332. [[VIDEOID:mo1L4P0VC2F1XAI]]FINALLY!! A dryer brush that works as good as, or better, than my old one! I just got this today and couldn't wait to try it out. The reviews indicated that it was worth the purchase, and it IS.<br /><br />4 years ago my trusty old conair dryer brush fell apart. I've been through 3 dryer brushes since then, none of which worked worth a darn, and didn't hold out much hope of finding one at all that would work with my thick longish hair.<br /><br />Well...my hair looks fabulous...BETTER than when I get it done at the salon. Seems no one at the salon ever listens to me and does my hair *exactly* the way I like it. Don't have to worry about that anymore. I can go back to doing it myself, and it looks just the way I want it. My hair is slightly curly and when left to air dry, it gets frizzy...and if they don't dry it COMPLETELY at the salon...it gets frizzy. No worries with this - I dry it until it slips through the bristles like silk and I know it's perfect. The bristles on this brush are really great with my hair. Most of the ones I've tried in the past few years have \\"hair type bristles\\" that will not go all the way through my hair and are a real pain. The bristles on this are a combination of hair and hard plastic bristles...exactly what is needed for thick hair...they work great.<br /><br />I saw where several people complained about the controls...I didn't find that to be a problem for me at all. They are right at the perfect place where I can easily slide it from low to high or to cool. I usually only use high anyway, but I didn't think it was an issue.<br /><br />I will post a video review when I get time.<br /><br />LOVE this product!<br /><br />*ADDED COMMENT* January 15, 2015: I am still using this dryer brush and still love it! I am purchasing one for my Mom, in fact. I would love to add a couple of before/after pics, but cannot figure out how to do that. This is the only drying tool I use, and 98% of the time, except for heat protectant, I don't use mousse or any other product to make my hair behave, and it's always perfect.ept for heat protectant, I don't use mousse or any other product to make my hair behave, and it's always perfect.
  333. This handy device dries my limp, fine hair and gives it body while drying it. I find that it works best for me by letting my hair partially air dry and then using the brush. I end up with a fuller hairdo that is flattering and easy to do. My fine hair takes a long time to dry (ask my hair dresser who can take 30-45 to dry and style it) and this drastically cuts down on the time and effort it takes while giving me the fuller hair that I like.
  334. I have fine, thinning, curly hair. This works great for me. I've never mastered the dryer in one hand and round brush in the other for straightening. This does both and leaves your hair frizz free. It works on damp or dry hair too. There is a design flaw in that if you push the on button all the way up it's only cool air. So to dry or style you have to leave it one notch down. I've seen where others have returned it because they thought it didn't get hot. The other great thing about this is the bristles. Conair, which makes this dryer, had a predecessor that was natural bristles that wore down over time. Other mfrs make plastic bristles that are too hard or don't grab the hair. This is perfect.
  335. I love this hot air brush - does a great job styling/smoothing my hair. You just have to remember it is a styling tool - not a blow dryer, so don't expect it to do more than style. Use it after blow drying and you will be happy with the results.

  367. This brush could use a few improvements, especially when compared to others that I have used. First, I agree with other users that the power/setting switch is oddly located in that it is sunk into the handle so it isn't easy to just adjust the setting. You actually have to stop what you are doing and look at the handle and make sure you have selected things properly. Other brushes have a more textured button or one that comes out from the unit a bit so they are easier to slide. Second, and perhaps most annoying for me personally, there is nowhere to \\"anchor\\" your other hand when you are holding the curl. I hold the brush with my right hand, roll the curl, and then have to hold the very flat end of the brush when I am holding the curl and the end is not only uncomfortable, it gets hot!! All curling irons and other blower brushes have a stump or cap that is cool for you to hold on to. This one is realllly lacking that feature. Last, the brush could get hotter and could have more power. I have thick hair and it takes forever to get the curl to set, and again, I've had better luck with other similar products.<br /><br />Also, don't buy this if you want curls, the barrel is quite large so it's designed for a \\"curve\\" and body effect for medium to long hair.<br /><br />Not a bad product but I'm not in love either.

Great product for the price, as long as it lasts. I highly recommend it!

I bought this to see if I really would use it (that is, if it is easy to use and effective) and I do!! Not too hot for my fine hair and the curl is a good size (would be GREAT to hava a 1 inch tho).   445. UPDATE.<br />I originally gave the brush 5 stars, I knocked it down to three because I purchased the first one on March 21, 2013, and it stopped making heat about a week before thanksgiving, that was just barely 7 months. I don't know why I thought I could put any faith into a conair product. I'll probably be contacting the company, but I am officially done with conair.<br />--------------------------------<br /><br />I was really skeptical about buying this brush, While it's marketed via john Frieda it's produced by conair...and a few years ago I ran into a big issue with conair's quality (I went through four $50 dollar infiniti air brushes in a year) and pretty much wrote the company off as garbage.<br /><br />So far I've purchased two of these and not because the original one is broken! My mother loved using my hot air brush and eventually had me order her one, and now I'm here to order one for my sister as well.<br /><br />Naturally I have wavy curly hair right from root to tip, while I like it, it get's messy way too easily. I've had this hot air brush for less than a year and it's lifespan is seems to be really holding up nicely.<br /><br />The large round barrel straightens my hair, gives it body and adds the perfect amount of curl at the ends. The large barrel also lets me pick up slightly bigger chunks of hair, I have below shoulder length hair and A LOT of it, doing my hair in one inch sections is not an option. As far as the Ion technology, not super sold on it, I don't notice it being any shinier from Ions compared to when I used to use my old round brush or the even infiniti brush.<br /><br />My only real complaint is waiting for my hair to be the perfect dampness, I find that I can't go into using the air brush with super wet hair as it takes way too long because the brush just doesn't have the air flow of a normal blow dryer And it can't be too dry either or I notice I get little waves where it just didn't take as well. it kind of has to be at that perfect spot, I believe the instruction booklet said 80-90% dry.<br /><br />The brush doesn't leave the tell tale signs of using a straightener, like leaving that weird mark near your scalp, or scalding your ends to where they look dry, infact a new friend of mine only just recently saw me without my hair done, she had no idea I had naturally curly hair, She insisted she could ALWAYS spot someone who straightens their hair. I think it killed her that I snuck right under her radar =P
  446. I've been letting my curly, thick hair grow longer this past year. ( now about shoulder length ) and also letting my colorist allow it to be much lighter. My hair is very unruly in humidity, although when blown straight by a professional, will usually retain body, and stay under control. Thus far I've been unable to attain these results with my own blow drying efforts. Enter this John Frieda hot Air brush. Unlike my old, 15 year old contraption that I found in the bottom of my drawer, this brush is sleek, and allows for consistent, easy drying and curling. My hair looks like I've just stepped out of the salon. it pulls easily through my hair, and allows for curling the ends. After wash, dry, and condition, I let my hair air dry for about 1/2 hour, then dried with the hot air brush in small sections. results are smooth, non frizzy, healthy looking hair. I'm really thrilled. Thank you!!!!

Make sure your hair is just damp or will take a long time to dry.   470. Before ordering, I had my doubts. I wasn't sure that this would work, but I figured that for around $30, it was worth a shot. My first impression when I unpacked the item was that there were hardly any bristles. Deciding that I shouldn't &#34;knock it until I try it,&#34; I washed my hair and let it airdry for about 10 minutes. I have shoulder blade length hair. It is very thin and frizzes when it's not styled. Due to the years of styling damage done to my hair, it's lost its natural curl in several places, leaving it wavy or really straight wherever it's not still curly.<br /><br />My hair was almost dry around my face, and everywhere else it was still pretty wet. I just couldn't wait to try it any longer. I started around my face, and immediately noticed that it was, indeed, working. I started at the root of my hair and continuously turned the hot airbrush while pulling it through my hair. When I would get to the ends, I would roll my hair back up and slowly pull the brush back to the ends. I ended up with a voluminous style, something I've always wanted but have never been able to achieve. I could even see where my layers were cut, and the style looked great!<br /><br />I typically blow dry my hair with my high dollar (Chi) blowdryer and flat iron. I can honestly say that my hair was just as shiny using this item, and it was softer! I never want to blowdry and flat iron my hair again. This item allowed me to style my own hair and make it look like I had just gotten it professionally blowdryed...and it took a fraction of the time that I usually spend with a blowdryer and flat iron. I also loved that my hair never got tangled with the brush while doing this. I, at first, considered a hot airbrush that would spin, but since you've got both hands to work with (since you're not having to hold a blowdryer too), turning this hot airbrush is not at all difficult.<br /><br />My only regret is that I didn't discover this item sooner! The one concern that I do have is that the bristles won't outlive the motor of this hot airbrush, since there don't seem to be a lot them. Only time will tell, but if that's the case, I'll gladly order another one.

  495. After using this for the first time, I walked out of the bathroom and my boyfriend told me it looked like I had just stepped off the runway! At first I was frustrated that you have to move the switch to the second-to-last click to get the hottest setting, but then realized that it's actually convenient to have the last click be the cold setting, because it helps set the curl - so going back and forth between hottest and cold is actually convenient. I would recommend this product for women on a budget, who still like to have fabulous waves in their hair. It probably works best on long hair, and with some leave-in conditioner and shine serum if you are prone to frizz (and to minimize heat damage). For those who only wash their hair every 2-3 days, the style lasts overnight fairly well, with just a few touch-ups in the morning.

  515. I decided to purchase the John Frieda Hot Air Brush after first seeing an ad for it in Cosmo, and then reading all of the fabulous reviews for it here on Amazon. I absolutely love this brush. It has greatly shortened my hair-doing process, and the results are seriously amazing. I have frizzy, overworked, kind-of curly, long hair. My usual process used to include first blowing my hair dry, then painstakingly straightening it, section by section. Because this process was pretty time consuming, I would usually blow dry at night, and straighten in the morning.<br /><br />With the Hot Air Brush, I simply blow dry in three sections, and walk out the door. The finish that this brush gives to hair is bouncy, light, and shiny. Also, like many of the other girls on here, I have to say that achieving cute, bouncy end-of-the-hair curls is a breeze with this tool. I keep getting compliments on how nice my hair looks, and I am thrilled with how much less time I am spending on my hair. Also, I am sure that not using my straightener is much better for my hair as well.<br /><br />Ladies- this tool is worth the $40, and it ships quick. Do yourself *and your hair* a favor and pick up this fabulous brush!
  516. I was super excited to try this because (1) I'm always looking for ways to battle frizzy hair, and (2) I generally love everything John Frieda. I was very disappointed in this product. It really didn't work any better than a traditional hair dryer and brush. My hair wasn't noticeably less frizzy nor shinier. But, I'm still giving this product 3 stars because I think its functionality depends on your hair type. My long and thick hair was just too much for this product to handle - even with drying it with a hair dryer first and sectioning it off. If you have short/thin hair, I'd probably recommend this product. But anyone with long/thick hair should probably look elsewhere.

  525. At long last I can finally get a salon-type result at home, despite being uncoordinated with a dryer/brush. My hair is fine in texture, but thick in quantity, and it works like a charm.<br /><br />First I apply argan oil serum to protect my hair, then I hit it with a regular hair dryer for a couple of minutes just to speed up the process. I use clips to section my hair, then I dry each section (starting from the bottom and working up) with this wonderful hot air brush, combing thru a few times to get maximum shine and smoothness. I'm able to use the brush to get great volume on the top of my head by simply holding the brush in place next to my scalp for a few extra seconds before sliding the brush through. The whole process is very quick, even for my mid-back length hair. The end result is smooth, shiny, and tangle-free. I'm so glad I didn't spend all that extra money on an InStyler. No way could it be better enough to warrant that expense.

I have been using this &#34;type&#34; of hot air brush for years and needed a new one. I checked the reviews here in trying to decide between this particular one and another brand that &#34;rotates.&#34; I settled on this one and I can't be happier! The bristles actually grab the hair (unlike my old one where the bristles were so short) and it literally leaves my hair shiny and smooth, unlike my old one which left my hair frizzy, necessitating the use of a curling iron and then a flat iron. I have also recently changed hair-care styling products and between those and this brush....I am able to clean out my closet of unneeded items like the curling iron and flat iron. Awesome! The reason I give it a 4.8 is that during styling I tend to need to hold onto the flat, top end of the brush with my other hand in order to rotate it during styling, and there isn't really much to grab onto it with since it is pretty flush with the bristles and that flat end does tend to get a bit hot. I'd LOVE it if it had just about an extra quarter or half inch or so beyond the bristles to be able to work easier with it...maybe like a small &#34;knob&#34; or something on that top end. However...it's definitely not a deal breaker. I love this brush!

  542. Excellent air brush - dries quickly, doesn't tangle or pull my thinning hair, comfortable grip doesn't make my hand cramp like a brush and blow dryer does! This one does not seem to get as hot as my Revlon air brush, but that's a good thing since the Revlon with the aluminum surface would burn my scalp and hair on the high setting (yes, it smoked). Do your hair a favor and get a microfiber towel just for drying your hair after washing. They soak up more water than a bath towel and decrease the drying time and damaging heat. Press and squeeze, don't rub, then apply good leave-in conditioner/heat protector. Use a regular dryer to get the hair about 3/4 dry, then style and finish with the air brush. The ceramic coating makes my hair smooth without burning and the brushes didn't pull or tangle my hair. Great brush for a medium length bob - would be perfect if it had a 2&#34; barrel option!

I chose the John Frieda, based on Amazon reviews, unsatisfied, I have now purchased a Revlon product, but it isn't &#34;just right&#34; either. This review compares the John Frieda product to the others I have tried.<br /><br />I have collar-length, naturally wavy/curly hair.<br /><br />PROS: The John Frieda brush feels sturdy in my hand (the Revlon brush feels 'cheap' and vibrates excessively). Easy to work with. Has held up in traveling (the Hot Tools brush had damage to the plastic vent covers the very first time I took it on a trip)<br /><br />CONS: Bristles, my hair prefers the simpler bristles on the Hot Tools and Revlon products. Power, this product only has 500watts (Hot Tools 1000w, Revlon 1200w), I use it on wet hair, so the bristles and power are not working for me. Not &#34;Ionic&#34; my hair seems to respond better to the ionic brushes (both Hot Tools and Revlon).<br /><br />Bottom line: If they could make just one change, increase the wattage to 800 or 1000, I would probably be happy enough with this product to stop looking. Adding &#34;ionic&#34; would be nice, too.
