I guess because they are shorter and the heat is really really HOT. I think you could burn your hair right off if you were not careful @500 watts. I used a spray for protecting hair from heat, then on the same line, a spray that was to help add curl, and finally I had to top it off with a really thickening mouse. I blowed my hair until it was damp. Then I started using this curler. I was able to section my hair into 1 for top, 2 for crow, and 3 for bottom. Then did 2 times each on the hair behind my ear. Then twice on the sides to uplift the roots and curl the ends. For the last 10 years I've just shampooed and blowed dried and slept on it...and it was fine. Now I've lost so much hair I HAD to do something. My hair dresser said \\"IT IS TIME TO USE A PRODUCT NOW EACH TIME!\\" Or else I am just going to have flat hair. ugh. I am 67 but just as vain as ever :>). So this is reminiscent of days gone by when I had an outside job and spent tons of time on my hair. Today my hair looks great...but living in Hawaii it picks up the moisture . The ions REALLY make your hair SHINE. But just remember you NEED to use some kind of heat protector or else you're going to fry your hair. I wish the little slide to change heat from low to high was easier to use when using the thing. Other than that I do really love it and my hair looks a LOT fuller. It takes both; product & curls to acheive this look.
  612. The barrel does not come off which has its pros and cons. The removable ones I tend to break anyway, but I like being able to use it to dry my hair, then snap the barrel on and curl it. Can't do that with this one. The barrel seems unusually large for 1.5 inches. Better for longer hair. Good heat, good airflow.
  613. I have very fine short hair. This works great for me because it's all I need to dry my hair and style. Easier to use than a blow dryer and brush. Great product.
  614. Did not work well with fine straight hair that has a lot of slip. I was optimistic about this product giving me body in my hair as it's completely flat on my head. It did not suit this purpose for me anymore than blow drying my hair upside down. It did not make my hair look any worse though, and did make an area around my face that looks a little damaged blend in more with the rest of my hair.<br /><br />I was also hoping beyond hope that this would help my bangs stay together and not split as I am trying to grow them out and they have been driving me nuts. This actually was much worse at that than a fine toothed comb and a regular blow dryer and they split once I was done.<br /><br />I have faith in this product from the reviews for girls with a different hair type and needs than my own so am going to let my friend with thick curly hair try it and hope it works miracles for her before I send it back.
  615. Lightweight and very easy to use. My hair looks and feels like I just had it blown out at the salon. I never write reviews, but had to with this one. I've owned others like this, but they usually rip my hair out or it gets snagged. I am thrilled with this item!!
  616. I like the hot air brush a lot but wish the barrel was a little smaller. My hair is just below my ears but really straight. So a smaller barrel would be better in my situation. I bought because it is much gentler on my hair, no more little burns on my neck from a hot metal barrel.<br />When my hair gets longer I am sure I will love it.
  617. I got this product expecting great results. I had some trouble getting the brushes to grab the crown of my hair & then was disappointed by the drying mechanism; it didn't do a great job of drying that section of the hair. The end result was that I could not style my hair right. I sent it back.
  618. I bought this to replace the conair hot brush I had for years. It's not the same quality my conair had, but it works. The conair was loud, but it blew a ton of air and was really hot. It got my long hair done in 10-15 mins from wet to dry. This thing is a little more quiet, but does not blow a lot of air and is not nearly as hot. It took me 25 mins to get it done this morning.<br /><br />I do like the deep, long bristles. They grab my hair very well and hold on to it. My old conair was still going strong, but the brush part was removable to switch to different sizes, and the connectors cracked. The brush no longer stays attached, so its useless. This one does not have a removable brush, so I see no reason for that to happen here. Overall, it seems more cheaply made than my conair. I hope it holds out in the long run.
  619. I just love this dryer! It is easy to use, and doesn't tangle my hair ( as a similar product did). And, it leaves my wavy hair sleek and smooth.
  620. These are a Christmas gifts for my daughter & daughter in law . Both have very long hair and I'm sure they'll get great use if these tools . Especially with their hectic schedules. They were delivered on time as expected.
  621. Loved the one that I got for myself,so ordered this for a birthday gift, works awsome on my thick long hair
  622. I really researched before choosing a hot air brush. This does do what is advertised. The only reason I gave 4 stars was because your hair really does have to be 80% dry before you can use the hot air brush. So depending on how much time you have you need to pull out the blow dryer too. I paired this with a john Frieda volumizing moouse. There are lots of helpful videos on YouTube as well.
  623. Very easy to use, even when you are not very skilled with hair styling. I have fine, straight hair, and this really helps with styling a natural looking Bob.
  624. Growing up in Japan, I've used many of these types of hot air brushes before. This is the first non-Japanese hot air brush I really like! The quality of the brush itself is really good. When I style my hair with this thing, my hair looks shinier than when I dry only with normal hair dryer and brush. By the way, the brush part doesn't rotate with this one. I also have one of those with a rotating brush, and while they may add even more shine, I like this one better because I think the rotating ones are more harsh on your hair, takes longer to style and harder to control.<br /><br />The positives:<br />1. It's very easy to control. I'm not very good at styling my hair especially in the back, but with this one my hair will have more \\"styled\\" look when I'm done. And it takes less time for me than a normal hair dryer w/ brush or a dryer w/ rotating brush.<br />2. The quality of the brush is really good. Not too hard & not too soft. Adds shine to your hair.<br />3. It's incredibly light.<br />4. The price is reasonable.<br /><br />But there are a few negatives:<br />1. It doesn't have a built-in transformer. This is the biggest negative for me, as I often travel to Japan (100v) and Italy (220v). I think any personal appliances you'd travel with such as compact hair dryer, chargers of laptop computers, tablet, cell phones, shavers, cameras, camcorders and so on, should have built-in transformers. I would've loved to take it with me to my next Italy trip only if it worked there. If you rarely travel to other countries this shouldn't be a problem.<br />2. The handle is big and it's kind of hard to have a good grip. Because you use it like a brush, I'd like a skinnier handle to have a better control. I have larger hands and it's not a big deal for me but if your hands are smaller you may have a hard time.<br />3. You cannot take off the brush part. If you could take it off, you could've used it as a regular dryer, which makes it convenient especially for travel. It would alsomade it easier to clean the brush part. Not a deal breaker though,<br />4. There is only one switch to control the air and the temperatures. Off - low - high - cool. I prefer to have two switches for air and temperatures so that I can go back & force from hot & cool no matter what air setting I have. No big deal.<br /><br />So, except the no transformer issue, for me, these negatives are all small issues. I would highly recommend this product!
  625. Love it! Hair gets smooth, the heat is ok and it is not noisy at all.
  626. When i saw this I HAD to try it! I always struggled with the whole hair dryer in one hand and brush in the other hand thing to dry my hair. This makes straightening my hair much easier, especially the back. The only thing is that for best results you need to either towel dry really well or blow dry all over for a few minutes otherwise it will take forever to dry using this alone. &#60;3

I can simply roll the hair onto the brush and the hot air dries it into a nice full style. It doesn't curl the hair, but it makes it full and soft with lots of volume.   635. So easy to use, left my hair shiny and bouncy and straight with zero frizz. Not as much control as, say, a flat iron... but they're different tools. Was much easier to use than a hairdryer and round brush.
  636. My heading says it all. I am well on my way to being a very mature adult (this means old) and have used hot air brushes for many, many years. This one needed to be in my life long, long ago. What is most impressive is lack of &#34;hot spots&#34;. Every other hot air brush I have owned over the years, including the one prior to this one, had extremely hot air at base of brush. Care has to be taken to avoid damaging hair. The other nice feature is the &#34;cool&#34; setting and it does lock in the curl. The only small, small issue I had when trying it out for the first time was the difficulty in turning it on and moving the control from one setting to another. The control is tight and doesn't slide easily. Other reviewers have expressed this as well. I have had this same problem with other hot air brushes and years ago found a solution. All it takes is a small piece of self stick Velcro attached to the control and you have all the stability and grip you needs. This little fix takes about one second to complete and doesn't affect handing. It didn't deter me from giving this little gem 5 stars because all of the other attributes out weigh this minor issue. Would love to have John Frieda manufacture hot air brush with smaller roller for shorter hair. How perfect would that be!
  637. I use this as a styler. I have never tried to dry my hair with it, so I can't review that aspect. This is - by far - my favorite hot air brush, and I've been using hot air brushes to style my hair for over 20 years! 500 watts is the perfect strength. I have one that's 250 watts, and it works well, but it it takes much longer. I have one that's 1250 watts, and it's way too strong... any styling is ruined because it gets blown the opposite way. I think a 750 watt hot air brush would be too high also because this one really is perfect!
  638. I use this when I travel as it saves room from having to pack round brushes and a hair dryer. Also was good to have when I had my arm in a sling. Easier to use with one arm than brush and hair dryer!

  648. Straight fine hair bobbed blonde hair--this is just OK. I had a heavy, loud, hot pink, Revlon hot brush. I thought this brush looked great and violated my usual policy of not buying another of the same thing while the old one still works. This Frieda brush works fine, is light, and much quieter. However, it seems to fill my hair with static. I don't get the same level of curl or control I got with the smaller barrel. In hindsight, the one inch barrel size would have been better. So, have gone back to the Revlon brush.
  649. This is a great product! I have extremely thick hair that goes to the middle of my back.   654. I'm not very talented when it comes to blow drying my hair, but you'd never know it when I use this hot air brush. I also have fine shoulder length hair and was concerned about the hair getting tangled on the brush. Regardless of the speed and where I place the brush on the hair, either at the root, middle or ends there are no tangles. I use another hair dryer to start the process (it speeds the drying time) and finish with the John Frieda dryer. Previously I dryed my hair about 90% and then used large rollers for the last 10% of the drying process to get the volumn. Lastly, I used the hair iron on the ends. I skip the roller step now and don't miss it a bit. I get all the volumn I want from the John Frieda hair dryer and finish with the iron if that's the look and style I want for the day. The dryer is light in weight, very easy to use and requires no learning curve. I got the style I was looking for the first time I used it.

  700. I use this with Sebastian Whipped Creme Light Conditioning style Whip, and obtain soft bouncy curls. I have pin-straight hair that barely holds a wave except when it's humid ;-&#62; I find it lightweight to hold and easy to turn a curl (even though I have a repetitive stress injury I get no pain when using this brush). I have no talent for styling my hair and have been amazed at how nicely this brush leaves my hair soft and wavy. I'm even thinking of buying a backup in case they stop making it, which happens with god many products I like. I'm not sure how the results would be with a different styling mouse or with thick hair, but this brush has given me a quick and easy way to add some swing to my hair!
  701. It basically just brushes the top layer of hair; it doesn't get all of your hair by any means. Does NOTHING for the rest. -_-
  702. Works really really well! I love it. I wash my hair at night and in the morning and completely dry it with this item. It gives me the volume I need.
  703. First let me note that I have thin, fine hair. This product does give my hair more body and a little curl. The only thing I would change about it is that I'd have the highest heat setting be the farthest up on the slide switch, rather than the cold air one (that I never use) for &#34;setting&#34; the style. This product is much more substantial than the last hot air brush I had. I do NOT use it as a hair dryer, though; that would take too long. When I either air dry my hair partway or use a regular hair dryer first, it works very well. I would NOT recommend it as your ONLY hair dryer, though.
  704. Bought for my wife. She says itdoes a great job. Loves it, although she wishes the barrel of the brush was slightly thinner. Brush grabs and holds the hair when drying and is soft enought so that when you go over your ear it doesn't hurt or scratch your ear.
  705. I usually blow dry my hair on the highest setting. This brush on high setting turns my hair too hot within seconds, it hurts to touch it. Also, while it dries the bottom, it doesn't dry the top. Anyway, due to it's being super hot, I have many split ends and breakage on ends. I'm going back to a traditional blow dryer; that way I can keep the heat further from my hair so it's not as damaging.
  706. This brush is very easy to use and it doesn't get so hot as to burn your hair. In fact, it leaves your hair silky and shiny, just as if you left the salon! Just make sure you allow your hair to dry somewhat before using it for best results. It would be nice to see a smaller barrel for the hair which could be interchangeable, but this size works nicely for medium length hair.
  707. Not what I was looking for the barrel was to big.
  708. This device was not what I thought it would be. This brush does not rotate. However, the bristle quality is nice and it does get me a little closer to looking like I had my hairdresser blow my hair straight (NOT as nice as the salon, but closer). It has made my hair shiny, straight, and frizz free, however it does absolutely zero in terms of adding volume. I'm not sure about curls yet--I'm still getting the hang of this thing. The air/ heat power is very good, but it does take a little longer than a regular hair dryer to get the job done.
  709. Bought for my mother to replace a 1970s wonder model that must have been made from early Apollo mission rejects. It finally kicked the bucket and she needed a replacement. Not made of nearly the same long lasting material as they used to, but works well. She is happy with it.

It seemed to take forever in order for it to work properly and get enough heat to the barrel to get my hair to set.   730. This Frieda Hot Air Brush is wonderful. It's very effective in creating smooth curls and volume. The heat level is great, and the brush is easy to use. I can take one section of hair that's been blown-dry and make terrific, smooth curls. My only complaint is that the small side panel for options (Hot, Medium, Cool, Off) is extremely awkward to use. After heating a curl, I have to maneuver the panel around to slide it to Cool. It's very user-unfriendly. I would strongly suggest to John Frieda that the next model of this Hot Air Brush include a Cool-Shot BUTTON so that the user doesn't have to try to slide the panel options up and down while holding the Brush in difficult position. If it's behind your head, you can't SEE where the COOL option is, and so you end up sliding the panel up and down.<br /><br />Please, John Frieda. Please. Put a Cool-Shot Button on the handle so that it's easy to cool down the curls quickly without fumbling and dropping the brush or getting the whole thing tangled in your hair.
  731. I think I was expecting for this to be the automatic kind, which it isn't. I was okay with that when I realized it, but I just haven't gotten a lot of use out of this product. It's supposed to give you a blowout effect, but the timing is incredibly tricky. You're supposed to dry your hair halfway or more with a regular blow dryer and then finish with this, which is a bit labor intensive. Then, by the time I get around half of my head with this, the other half has already air dried. I use it on my bangs, so it isn't a total waste, but I wouldn't have paid the money if I knew I would only use it for that.

This combination makes it difficult to find the right styling instruments in one product. But I've found it with this. I'm SO HAPPY with this product and I highly recommend it.

It didnt work for me, and I will be returning for sure. I even watched the videos to make sure I knew how to use it. I was even going to give it a second chance... But by the end I was so frustrated there's no way I'm using it again.<br /><br />I was hoping the hot air brush would do the following:<br /><br />1. Help cut some time with the hair dryer. It did not! I let my (long, semi-thick) hair air dry for 30 minutes and found I still had to dry with the blow dryer for another few minutes. The brush did not dry my hair AT ALL. I don't have time for that in the morning.<br /><br />2. Get rid of those awful lines I always seem to get in the same spot because my hair is too long to use a brush and dry at the same time. It did not! I used the brush over the hair...under the hair...made several slow passes... I can do it in seconds with my straightener.<br /><br />3. Add some volume at the roots. Nope. I used the brush exactly how you are supposed to: Hold for 10 seconds or so at the roots, slowly pull brush up. No volume.<br /><br />4. Add shine and control frizz. I don't really have a problem with frizz unless it is super humid, and I didn't notice an increase in shine.<br /><br />5. Be easy to maneuver around my head. The design is difficult to manage. My hands are small, and it was difficult to hold and control the brush. I lost a few bristles taking it out of the package, and it doesn't have many to begin with, so a few lost during each use is substantial.<br /><br />If you really want to try this product, then try it. It didn't work for me, but I'm apparently in a minority because the majority of reviewers loved it.

If I had the time, I would just use this anyways because I loved the whole effect in the end. If I was very short on time, I would dry my hair with a normal blow dryer and then go over the top parts of my hair to make it look nice and sleek. This is amazing for reducing frizz!!! It is also great to give extra volume if you hold the dryer at your roots for a little bit before dragging it down.
  788. When reading a product review, it's important to know what the writer's needs were, to evaluate if their advice is applicable to yourself. So I will say, I have very fine, medium short, straight hair and this is a fabulous hot brush for my type of hair. The wider diameter of the wand gives me the slight curve under I want, and very soft bristles do not rip my hair out. My hair dries in literally less than three minutes. If you have thick, long, wavy, coarse hair this is not the brush for you.
  789. Does not get hot enough
  790. This is the best styling tool I own!<br />I am fairly incompetent when it comes to doing hair. I can put in a pony tail, maybe a headband or barrette and even managed a messy bun on occasion. I have pretty fine hair that is fairly straight buy not that pretty sleek straight just blah hang there with occasional waves. I absolutely adore the ease of this tool. I can style and dry simultaneously and style my hair. I can get great body and shine while straightening out those funky parts in my hair. It is simple enough that I can do it.
  791. Like this better than my Infinity curling brush! The smaller barrel creates the look I want.
  792. I have very fine hair and this is PERFECT for it. It does not work as great on my daughter's hair since her hair is super thick.
  793. I don't use this as a curler - I use it to straighten out my hair in the morning. I sometimes go to bed with my hair wet and end up with weirdly shaped hair in the morning. This is much better than a straightening tool because it doesn't hurt my hair as much.<br />However my hair does tend to get tangled in the brush a lot. Not that it doesn't happen with other brushes so I won't take points off for that. Overall very happy with my purchase!
  794. I have very limited use of my hands because of a spinal cord injury and I have a short stacked bob hair cut so drying it while using a round brush is not possible for me. I often go to my hair dresser just to get my hair styled because it looks so much better when its done with a round brush. This item has helped me a lot. Is it perfect, no, but that's just because of my limitations. I personally would benefit more from a smaller handle and harder bristles because my hair is thick even though it's short. I'm also afraid of burning my hand on the very top part of it while trying to hold my hair around the brush. But like I said it does make my hair look healthier, shinier, and more polished. It's not hanging there looking lifeless. It gives me good volume. This is the first time I've used something like this and I don't feel the need to keep looking for another one.
  795. Brush was used and had lots of dark hair on the bristles
  796. I ordered this based on the reviews & because I'm completely uncoordinated with styling tools. The first time I got it I thought no way is this thing going to dry my extremely thick, shoulder- touching hair. This tool must be for people with thin hair. But to my surprise it dried it & it didn't take all that long. I got lots of compliments & I didn't even have to use a curling iron. Smooth, cute curls! I'm lazy so I wanted to try cutting down on the drying time. So, the next time I dried it with my Solia Thermal Ionic (love it- dries my hair 10 min flat whereas normal hair dryer 30 min) more 60-70% as suggested but I didn't get as nice a curl and it was frizzier. So here's my tips: I first dry my hair upside down about 60-70%. Then, as another reviewer suggested, I use a flat nozzle to dry the crown & roots. Next, dry it like the hairdressers do` pulling & rolling, pulling & rolling. Lastly, unless I'm in a hurry, I place each dried piece on those self-grip rollers until cool. Voila!

  897. Received this as a birthday gift and I don't know how I didn't know it existed sooner. As someone who's spent years on smoothing treatments, keratin, flat irons, etc. - anything to get my frizzy, half curly/half wavy hair to be a little bit straighter and smoother - this has changed my life. I dry my hair about 75% (either with a dryer or air dry), and then go through in sections. It's like using a round brush, except it actually stays shiny, silky, and smooth, like I just walked out of the salon after a blowout. I was amazed. I woke up this morning after using it last night and my hair is still just as smooth with a little volume/body on the ends, just how I like it. Plus, I don't feel like I'm getting nearly as much heat damage as I did from flat irons and wands. Super glad I found this!

  962. ...and I like them both! They are just different. I will try to describe those differences here to help people who are trying to decide between the two.<br /><br />Conair SpinBrush: I have had this one for about a year now, and once I figured out the rotation directions (after only a few uses) it's a breeze to use. I have never had it get tangled in my hair, but I also do not use the spinning feature constantly since my hair is fine textured and that would just result in static, frizz, and probably some breakage. I mainly use the spin feature to &#34;grab&#34; onto my hair, then let it sit for a few seconds to create shape and volume, then spin the opposite direction to release. I usually only use the low setting, and it gets plenty warm enough to do what I need without being overly hot. I don't find the unit heavy or uncomfortable to use, though I only use it to finish shaping my hair when it's mostly (90%) dry. It's a 2&#34; brush so it is larger than my new 1.5&#34; John Frieda Hot Air Brush, but it worked great on my medium-long hair. However, I recently cut my hair back into a chin-length bob, so it's a little too large to work on my shorter hair for right now.<br /><br />John Frieda Hot Air Brush: I purchased this one to try with my shorter haircut and have had it about a week, so here are my initial reactions in comparison to the SpinBrush: (1) I don't miss the spinning because I don't find it necessary -- the bristles of this brush &#34;grab&#34; my hair just fine without it, and (2) it is definitely hotter, since I have only used the low setting on it as well. Due to the heat and smaller size, this one seems to make a more defined curl at the bottom of my hair, and since I can get it closer to the roots I get more volume there as well. In fact, the first time I tried it I made my hair HUGE!<br /><br />So overall, based on my experience with both products I would recommend them for fine to medium textured hair, and definitely one of the JF brushes if your hair is above your shoulders. Those with longer, thicker hair may be able to take more advantage of the continuous spinning feature of the Conair, but I can't really speak to that. The Conair's bristles are a bit softer so it needs its spinning feature to really get ahold of the hair, while the JF brush is more like a regular round brush. They are both great products for those of us who have never bothered mastering the round brush blowout technique!

I let my hair dry at least 50% and then use this for a fabulous look - lots of compliments. It's great for touching up too.

  1022. I scoured videos online for feedback and usage tips on different air brushes. I picked this one because the barrel was sufficient, and the videos I found showed exactly what I was looking for in a hot air brush.<br /><br />I've used this on dirty, greasy hair as well as clean hair. I have fine, but thick hair with natural waves and highlights that go bananas in humidity. My bangs have a cowlick. This hot air brush eliminated my bang cowlick, and does not feel like it would do long term damage to my fine hair. When I style my hair with it, some of the styling lasts even through the next day and I don't use a lot of product on my hair. Not to say everyone will have the same results, but I have found this item works great for me.<br /><br />I like that it is lightweight, and has a cool and hot air selection. The 1.5 inch barrel works well for me with my hair at about shoulder length. The plastic tip does get really warm, almost too hot to the touch. But I have found that I really don't need to handle the unit with more than one hand now that I have the hang of it. It is a bit quieter than my Chi hairdryer, so that is nice.   1091. I'm getting GREAT results with this!<br />The bristles are soft enough to not tear & break my hair, and yet I have no trouble with how well they grip and go through my hair. I've also noticed my hair dries faster with this dryer.<br />I find the air flow to be just right. I dry my hair from towel dried wet, and this dries it nicely and with a gentled more concentrated flow so as to not cause all those little hairs to stand up and look awful. The drying power is all there though.<br /> I like having 2 heat choices as well as a cool flow.<br />The barrell is just the right size for my almost to shoulders bob, but I have some layering on top, and this gives me just enough lift & volume too. My hair is frizz-less & smooth & shiney with curl at the ends.<br />Some reviewers complained of the tip being too hot. I am able to touch it with 2 fingertips for guidance w/out a prob, just as I did with a previous unit I had. Didnt bother me.<br />What would have bothered me would have been if the cord constantly tangled... It doesn't.<br />Really happy with this brush dryer...and have received compliments on my hair since using it. Doesnt get any better than that!<br /><br />UPDATE...unfortunately I had to return this dryer after a bit due to a build up of static electricity in my hair that worsened with each use. Dont know why. Became impossible to style hair. Dropping a star as a result. Too bad, because I liked this one otherwise.
  1092. My hair is super fine but thick and frizzes up. I use this after using a regular dryer to get my hair about 90% dry. I brush through a small section til I get to about 3 inches from the bottom and start to curl the hair up until I get to the end and roll it up half way up my head. I'll hold it there for about 15-30 seconds then switch to the cold setting for another 10-15 seconds and then move on to another section. I end up with very smooth hair and very flattering big curl at the end. It does take some time to get the heat to really penetrate but my hair is very difficult with holding curl do this might not be an issue for everyone. Great tool!
  1093. The brush works well on fine hair, but next time I will order differently, with one that has a rotating brush & There are 3 settings on one switch making transitions to different settings awkward. The single switch includes a low heat, high heat, & the cooling setting. If there was a separate cooling button ( similar to a hair dryer)nstyling would be easier and quicker.
  1094. I really like this brush the only reason I gave it four stars is because the handle is so big around. I would like it better a bit more slimmer. I have smaller hands maybe.   1106. At first I found it quite awkward to handle - I have small hands and the base is much wider than a blow dryer and wider than a hairbrush. But I thought I'd better try it for a while before I gave up on it, and I've decided that it DOES work for me. I find that because of the awkward grip I need to use two hands: one to control my hair, and one to hold this brush. However, to use a regular blow dryer I'd really need 3 hands to do it right, and I've never been able to find that 3rd hand. So this ends up being easier to use than my regular blow dryer/brush combination, and I think my hair looks better. I find it is easier to dry in layers with this tool, which results in straighter hair; and it is easier to go over the same patch of hair, which also straightens it further. I've seen some complaints about the lack of heat/power on this, but I just let my hair get mostly dry before I start using it, and then it goes quickly enough. And I think that the lack of blowing is a good thing - it's easier to control the hair on the brush, which then results in a smoother result. (FYI: I have shoulder-length curly/frizzy hair, not super thick)
  1107. Good feel, lightweight and works great! This does a great job drying your hair and is very easy to handle
  1108. I had high hopes for this. This would work best for short hair. Not enough power to dry long hair. I wish it was more powerful!
  1109. Easy to use, made my hair much smoother than using a brush AND blowdryer. Lightweight, just hope it will last!
  1110. I like it a lot, though might not be as good at holding a curl as I'd like. Glad to have the right size as the other I had that was much more expensive was huge and very hard to manage.
  1111. I was really excited to get this product because, as far as I can tell, it is the only hot air brush on the market with such a large brush head. I bought it while visiting family and spent well more than Amazon sells it for so I could have it right away. It's a very nice appliance with one important exception, it is seriously underpowered at 500 watts. My [[ASIN:B003JMYYQW Jilbere Hot Air Brush]] is 1000 watts and works great with the exception of the small diameter brush head. If only the John Frieda brush had increased the wattage, I would keep this and be a happy owner. Until then, it takes too long to dry my hair, even from damp, and with the extended exposure to heat, it will likely cause excessive damage as well.
  1112. I like this hot air brush a lot. Have not used my hair dryer since I purchased it a couple of months ago.   1114. Product update: I bought this hot air brush 5 or 6 years ago and it's still works perfectly. Love it.<br />I use a hair dryer to damp dry my hair, then use this styler to smooth. I have straight, fine shouider length hair, and a few cowlicks that create an uneven appearance; This styler tames the cowlicks better than the other 5 or 6 styling brushes I have gone through. Most other stylers have lasted about a year, then short out where the cord it is attached to the base of the barrel. The swiveling cord base on this model might guarantee a little more longevity. Plus, it's quieter and feels a little more substantial, but not heavy. Maybe better insulation.<br />The only issue I have is the sliding on/off button. The raised lines on the sliding button aren't substantial, and if you have any product on your finger, you won't be able to slide the button, no traction. When I start to curl the next section, I often have to re-grasp the styler and use my fingernail to pull the slider back to the heat setting. Aside from button issue, very pleased with this product. Glad I switched from buying yet another styler at the local pharmacy to the Frieda air brush.

  1117. I tried this brush after going through countless Conair Infiniti Hair Designers that burned out after less than a year. Initially I had planned to buy the Conair Infiniti rotating brush because it appeared that you could remove the brush unit to clean it (thus preventing the burn out problem with the Designer) and the rotating brush feature. However, the 2\\" barrel of the Conair was just too large for my baby fine, not-quite-shoulder length hair. I then saw the John Frieda brush and with the 1 1/2 inch barrel, it's perfect for my hair. It has 3 settings, low, high and cool. I use the higher setting just for time savings. My hair dries quickly and has lots of volume. I only gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because the tip gets a little too hot on the high setting to handle if you want to \\"guide\\" the brush. However, the brush is light enough that \\"guiding\\" is not really necessary. It would be nice though if there was a tip that was cooler to the touch.

I stuck with it for the first dry anyway to see how my hair would come out, and because it took SO LONG, my hair didn't even look smooth afterwards. It was almost like my hair was air drying as the brush was &#34;doing it's thing.&#34; I returned this product. Dries my hair in 10 minutes (and I have thick, past-shoulder length hair!) It's the Panasonic KURUKURU Low-Noise Dryer PINK EH-KA15-P(Japan Import) -- you can see my detailed review about it there.   1128. I really like the bristle style and spacing of this brush, they're durable and placed for optimal venting, but I wish the fan was stronger. I thought the cord would be a little cumbersome, but I keep it half-bound with the cord-collector it came with and it works great with the swivel bottom, no tangles or swirling. The bottom is easy to remove for cleaning the intake vent and snaps on with a nice 'click', I don't think it will just fall off and roll away.<br />All in all, a really nice tool, but the fan could use a boost, I usually run the brush on low alongside my hairdryer on cool to decrease my styling time.

I have another hot air ion brush this size, but it's so hot I have actually burned my ears. This one didn't seem like it would do that. But after using it my hair was flat, limp and had little to no \\"curl\\" on the ends. I kept trying options: more time on high, cooling and every combination I could think of, but the result was the same--lifeless hair. Maybe the extra ions cause it. So reluctantly I returned it and went back to my old \\"too hot\\" brush. At least in a matter of minutes I'm fluffed from sleeping or tamed from drying and ready to go--if I can just keep from burning my ears. If you want flat, smooth, mostly straight hair this would likely work for you. It wasn't what I needed.

  1169. This is certainly much easier than using a traditional blow dryer and a separate round brush -- I always felt like I needed three hands to juggle those tools! I was afraid my fine hair would slip through the brush, but the bristle grip my hair great! The brush works pretty well, but since it's less powerful it does take a bit more time than a dryer with a separate brush. I also can't get my wavy hair quite as straight as with a dryer and brush, but it's pretty close. My hair is so shiny, soft with volume, I can give waves to my hair and also get it straight with this, the fact that this is ment to be used when the hair is almost dry is great because the hair is less exposed to heat damage, some people complain that it cant used on wet hair but its supposed to be like that and its so much better, thanks John freida for this product I just wish I had discover this earlier.

  1239. I have fine textured wavy hair -- it is quite thick and about mid way between chin and shoulder, all one length. I wash it every day at the gym, so am always looking to find ways to accelerate drying and styling. For years I have been using a flat iron after completely drying. I can usually get from dry to completely styled in about five minutes, with acceptable results. I was intrigued by the idea of a drying brush after seeing some of the other women at the gym using them. I picked the John Frieda after researching them because I liked that it did not rotate-- this just seemed like it would have more moving parts to fail, without adding functionality. I liked the wider brush as I am trying to straighten waves, but still get my hair to turn under. The iron was good for this but left my hair almost a little too flat.<br /><br />The very first time I used the Frieda brush I knew it was going to be a keeper for me. I still dried my hair-- but not completely -- saved a little time there. The brush gets plenty hot and quickly finishes the drying. I spend about as much time with the brush as I had with the iron -- may-be a little less. What I really like is that this brush gets your hair smooth and turned-under but without flattening it as much as using the iron. It has much more volume. I still need to fine tune the process but I think I really do prefer this to the iron. The brush is easy to use, is quite hot enough on the high setting and gets your hair smooth on the cool setting. I agree with the other poster that buttons or a turn button would be better than the slide control but this is really a tiny nit.

I also cut approx 10 inches to make a shoulder-length bob. My hair is very fine, but there is a lot of it. So... the bleaching damaged the ends and the remainder of the hair was pretty frizzy/slightly damaged and unruly. Just when I thought \\"ok, sick of it, I'm going to a \\"boy-cut\\", I saw the dryer offered on Amazon. Purchased it. Used it. Now that my hair is smooth and I'm able to give it some body and control with this dryer, I am keeping it shoulder length and bobbed. I recommend the product to anyone who wants control over their dry, damaged, course or fine, or over-processed hair. Fabulous product John Frieda.
  1278. Works very well. The only reason why I'm giving 4 stars is because you still have to dry you hair with a blow dryer until its about 85% dry. This product did save me from having to damage my hair even more with a flat iron, so if you're looking to save your hair from being damaged and still want some curl in the ends I WOULD RECOMMEND THIS PRODUCT

  1305. When my old one went kaput I needed a new one - the 1.5&#34; size was not easy to find - but I found it here with this John Frieda Hot Air Brush. I used it for the first time yesterday and am veryy satisfied with it. My tip is the same as other reviewers: Don't use it on totally wet hair. Partially air dry or blow dry your hair first - then do one section at a time - using clips to pin-up top layers in order to do underneath layers first. I know from experience that when you use this when you first wash your hair you can then get at least 2-3 days out of your style, using the brush on slightly dampened hair each day to freshen it up. Personally, I can go a week - but I know a lot of people find that gross - but really with hair like mine it works best in order to achieve the texture needed for most hairstyles. I also use Volumizing Powder - which is a fantastic invention for people with fine/slippery hair.<br /><br />I have issues with static using the brush and need to find a solution for that. Once I do I'll add another star to this review. I'm sure that using an additional hair product (or Static Guard) will take care of that issue. This tool is super easy to use - much better than a blow dryer and a round brush - which I have always found very cumbersome to do. Very good price on this too!

If you have a lot of hair like I do, blow dry it 80% dry then section your hair and blow dry each section.   1328. I recently went to Europe and stupidly used a Conair hot air brush that I'd had for about 8 years that worked wonders on my flat, pin straight hair. My beloved brush burnt out because of my idiocy, so that is when I began my search for a new brush. After much consideration, and reading all the rave reviews for the John Frieda Hot Air Brush, I thought I'd give it a try.<br /><br />Having a lot of fine hair, I don't get much volume, body or bounce naturally. This brush does very little to help it. The bristles don't grab the hair to give it a nice curl at the end, and you really have to work the same bunch of hair continuously (much longer than I feel is normal) to get any sort of shape. On top of that, there is NOTHING to hold onto at the end so my fingers are constantly getting burned. As if that weren't enough, the handle is very large so it's quite awkward and difficult to get a comfortable grip. At $30 plus I think this product is over priced for it's performance. I don't even mind the wattage...I usually mostly dry my hair any ways, but I think I'll be looking for a better replacement soon.

  1337. After reading all the reviews, I decided to try this and provide my own opinion about this product. Being a former hair dresser myself, I've always known that regular blow dryers are very harmful for your hair. Hence I have been considering buying a salon chair dryer to sit under while I dried my hair after setting them up in rollers. That's because those expel very low energy hot hair that slowly dry the hair without damaging. After reading some negative reviews about the low wattage, I thought this would be more beneficial rather than a negative. And sure enough, it does! In fact, I have been able to dry my hair right out of the shower within 10 mins. I'm not sure why everyone sees the low energy drying as a negative, when high energy is clearly bad for your hair. Plus this dryer does not tangle up my hair while drying, and leaves it soft and shiny after. I have fine hair, but a lot of them. So my experience has been great with this product. The size of the brush is as large as my rollers, so it works perfectly to add a bit of volume to my hair while allowing it to become curvy-straight. I think this is a wonderful dryer brush and now I can put my straightening iron (which was equally as damaging to my hair) away for good! :) Thank you John Frieda.

The reviews were great on this so I figured I would give it a try. What I do is dry my hair with the hair dryer till it is about 80% dry. Then I use the hot air brush to style, and the results are awesome! The first day I used this, I had 2 people ask if I had my hair blown out. Give it a try!
  1374. This product rocks my socks off! I have very fine, but thick and wavy hair. It can get very frizzy!   1376. I read all the reviews and really wanted to love this. I have thick, long, fine hair. I have to blow-dry or it is a frizzy mess. My arms hurt from holding the blow dryer and a round brush to get that &#34;blowout&#34; look. I figured this might be a two-in-one product that would work for me. I used my hairdryer until my hair was about 85-90% dry and then used this. It doesn't tangle in my hair at all. It does give a smooth effect. It just doesn't dry fast enough for me. If you have very thick hair, this is just going to take forever to get your hair dry. I used it for 30 minutes *after* I used my regular hairdryer to get my hair almost dry. And I still had a damp spot in back of the head---damp hair=frizz. Back to the drawing board for me.
  1377. It does what it's supposed to do but it is not at all powerful. Does not seem to get hot enough or blow enough air and really only works if your hair is mostly dry already. I've had others like this that I liked much better and this one was very disappointing

  1429. I was using a circular brush and hairdryer to style my chin-length, baby-fine hair. It got complicated when I tried to do the back of my head. I read a ton of reviews on hot air brushes, and chose this one. So often I buy things with high hopes, but end up being disappointed in some way. Not so with this device - I've been using it for about a month, and it has been absolutely ideal. It is much easier to use than the hairbrush/hairdryer combination.<br /><br />Before buying, I noted that some users found the high-temp setting to be quite hot, and this is true. However, the &#34;cool&#34; setting, which is the next slide up on the control switch from the &#34;high&#34; setting, helps moderate the temperature, and it's easy to slide back and forth. Moreover, it's nowhere near as hot as my curling iron, which baked my fine hair and burned my skin. The curling iron has been retired.<br /><br />My hair stays fairly well-shaped all day, even in the high humidity we have here in Florida.

But it turns out that it works fine on medium-length hair, too.<br /><br />If I have time, I let my hair air-dry until damp, then use this for styling. If I don't have time, I partially dry my hair with a blowdryer, then use this for styling. I used to use a straightening iron to get the top layers sleek, but I much prefer this, as I'm able to brush and dry all the layers of my hair, not just the top.<br /><br />My only quibbles: the cool setting blows just as hard as the high/hot setting. Seems it should be low cool, not high cool. A few bristles fell out the first couple times I used it, but that seems to have stopped now.<br /><br />The cord is plenty long enough. The price is right. If you are trying to tame thick, wavy hair, I recommend this product.

  1475. This not a time saver. Just to be clear, this one does not spin. But, I do like the end result. I just think you need to let your fair dry a bit before using. It does produce a nice result and is likely a bit easier than holding a brush and dryer. But you still need to section your hair, blow a bit at a time, etc.

  1480. This probably works better with thinner or lighter hair.   1481. With a fractured collarbone I was desperate to find something I could dry my hair with with one hand. This seemed like a good choice based on some reviews. It should be clearly understood that with the exception of those with VERY thin hair, this is not a hair dryer, it is a hair STYLER. It would take me hours to actually dry my hair with this even after air towel and air drying my short layered hair. I ended up using my regular dryer first, then using this to manage it and style it which it worked well for. THEN I had to flat iron it anyway. There is little air flow and little heat.<br />I guess ill use it until I have fully recovered, it does serve my purpose of not having to use 2 hands to manage my hair, but after that, probably not. It creates cute curl after a while, which made it easier to flat iron, and I probably could have gotten away without using the flat iron, but I sort of looked like an episode of Mad Men, with 60's kind of curl, like I had used rollers.
  1482. I use this every day- it's not as evil to the hair as my regular hair dryer and i love that it curls the hair for you - it is easier than holding the hair dryer in one hand and the round brush in the other and having your arms ache!
  1483. Thought it was a revolving brush but it's not. It doesn't straighten hair well at all.
  1484. After reading several good reviews, I decided to give this a try. Its not a bad product, but my hair is very finicky and this was not the solution. I was hoping I could use this and not have to use a chi straightener on my hair anymore, but no such luck. My hair is thick, but fine, and extremely wavy/curly. Most days I just leave it that way, but sometimes I like to straighten it.   1485. I have been using this brush for about a week and it is perfect for me. I have medium-long curly hair which is fairly fine. It has essentially taken the place of my hair dryer! I towel dry and let my hair air dry while getting ready. (But if I'm in a hurry I quickly blow dry for 2-3 min. until it's about 80% dry as recommended). Then this brush is used for styling/straightening. It does a much better job than a brush and hairdryer together and most importantly- IT DOES NOT GET STUCK IN MY HAIR! yeah. This brush straightens and curls my hair way better than a regular round brush and it doesn't pull out my hair the way a traditional brush does. In less than 10 minutes, my hair looks like it was styled in the salon. Would highly recommend!<br /><br />I've read some of the negative reviews, and I think whether you will like this brush really just depends on your hair type. I don't see this being easy to use with really long and/or thick hair.
  1486. It is a good air brush, but they need to make some improvements. I almost returned it after I turned it on and was getting cold air instead of hot, until I looked at it under the light to discover that the highest setting is cold, so you have to go down one little notch to set it on heat. This does not make sense to me, since the hot hair appliances I have own, the higher you go up, the hotter it is. It just makes sense that any setting starts with cold and goes up to hot. The other problem is the tip of the brush; IT GETS HOT! You tend to grab that end automatically to help roll the hair and you get a burning surprise. Other than that; it performs weil.
  1487. I've always wondered how hair stylists make it look so easy… They blow-dry your hair and make it look so amazing! You think &#34;I can do that! I tie part of my hair up and work in sections, applying hair serum when I need it. My hair has more volume than I've seen in a long time and I can manipulate hair waves or flips as well.   1517. This review compares the John Frieda Salon Shape 1.5 Inch Hot Air Brush to the Perfector. I vastly prefer the Perfector over the &#34;Salon Shape&#34;. I have long, fine, color treated hair. The Perfector works on dry hair. The Salon Shape's biggest disadvantage is that it requires that hair be WET to work. So the Salon Shape is inconvenient to use for a quick touch-up, or say after work when going out. The Salon Shape merely gives the same results on my hair as a brush and blowdryer - but because it is a self-contained unit, it can be done one handed, and is much easier to use than a brush-plus-blow-dryer. However, the Salon Shape requires repeated strokes to get a curl (like a blow dryer) and the curl did not hold on my fine, straight hair. (It may be good for straightening??) The curl from the Perfecter only requires one stroke - and lasted much longer! Also, using the Perfector at my roots added nice volume that lasted all day. I did NOT notice improved &#34;shine&#34; from EITHER product. The &#34;Salon Shape&#34; does not require warm-up time (but it still takes longer to use). The Perfector requires warm-up time - but that is usually under one minute! For straight fine hair, I recommend the Perfector...to me it is worth the extra money. However, the Salon Shape is a good alternative to a round-brush-and-blow-dry, if that is all you are looking for.

I just loosely dry my hair with the hair dryer until it's about 80% dry and then finish with the hot air brush. Or I let it dry naturally to 80% and then finish with the air brush. I was worried that my hair would catch in the brush, but it doesn't. I just roll, wait 8-10 seconds, and then twirl my hair loose. I also use it at the roots for added volume. My hair dresser just told me that I'm doing so much better styling my hair, and I told her it was because of this hot air brush. I need less hair styling product with this, too, which saves me money.   1641. I've been trying out different style hot air brushes, and seem to like this one better than others, for the following reason (BTW: I've got shoulder length hair, cut in layers, and I wear it kind of like a long &#34;shag&#34; style, so I'm not looking for tight curls): The size of this barrel is perfect if you're not looking for small or tight curls. It's 1 1/2 inches, which is the largest I've found ... perfect for longer cuts where curls aren't the goal, but soft waves are. The bristles on this one have a combo of black plastic ones, with a single plastic one with the &#34;dot&#34; on the end of it, which makes it &#34;grab&#34; onto your hair so you can actually brush with it. Others, same size, but different type bristles, w/o that &#34;dot&#34; that this one has, don't let you grab your hair to actually get it to brush through it. For this reason, I may keep this one, even though I like a different one (which rotates, and is the same size. That one is difficult to actually get to grab onto my hair to brush with it.) Also, be aware that these don't blow very strongly, like a hair dryer, but if you leave it on high, it DOES get hot. Hot enough so that when using your hands to keep your hair wrapped around the barrel, you can burn yourself if you're not careful. It's NOT like the ones that you can touch and don't get hot. These DO get hot when using the high setting, but you don't get much power or air coming out of it. I think I'm still &#34;in search&#34; for the perfect tool. Good luck!

My hair is very wavy in the back near the roots, and this brush pulls that out to an extent, but does not fully straighten or smooth it. I do like the end result because my hair is smooth and shiny. I turn the brush on before I actually use it, so it can warm up. I leave it running between hair sections so it remains warm and more effective. The bristles are soft and pliable, but strong enough for my thick hair. The barrel does not rotate. Many years ago, I broke my right wrist and had bad hair for 2 months cuz I was in a cast. I used an air brush like this, using only my left hand and it is what saved my style. I do wish they would make one of these that has more air power. While this is adequate, and better than the Helen of Troy, it could be much more powerful and more effective.

The trick is to dry your hair about 80% before using it. I have both air dried and used a hairdryer-still great results. Thank you John Frieda!!!

  1660. Have been trying to grow my hair out and was really struggling with making it look good during the transition. This tool is perfect! Better tan hot rollers, in-styler, etc. I have very think hair so I get it almost dry then use the hot air brush to finish drying and style. I have about a dozen different styling tools and this is my current favorite.
  1661. The thing that irritates me the most about this product is that my ability to return it just expired. It does not work at all, it is easily the most useless hair styling product I have ever bought in my life. I would be less angry if I got my money back, but now I just have an ugly paper weight on my hands. DO NOT BUY.
  1662. I read a ton of reviews before buying this because I definitely wanted a hot air brush and wanted to get the right one. I have past the shoulder, straight, highlighted hair that needs styling or it just looks like a frizzy mess. I bought this as a replacement for 1) my flat iron, to reduce hair damage, and 2) my nice round brush I use to attempt to get the blow out your hairdresser gives you - you know ladies, where your arms about fall off. I was either going to get this one or the Conair Spin Pro (the John Frieda is by Conair, too). After seeing the bulk of the other one in the store, I opted for this one. I think the auto spinning is kind of a novelty anyway and appears prone to breaking from the reviews. When I got this in the mail, I was immediately impressed that it was lightweight. Like others have mentioned, it would be tough to tangle your hair in it. I was worried that it wouldn't be hot enough, but it was. The heat is instant and it is as hot as my hair dryer, but not super hot, which was good since I'm trying to minimize damage. (If you want a super hot air brush, Sally's Beauty has a popular one.) The slide switch gives you 4 options - heat/low, heat/high, cool/high and off. The switch isn't perfect, but it is flat so you don't bump it accidentally, I'm sure that was the point of the design. My hair normally dries quickly - probably 7-9 minutes with a blow dryer. I did my whole head from towel dry the first time to see how long it would take and it took 15 minutes all in. Drying from root to tip and then rolling my hair with the brush gave it body and model-like bounce. I pinned it up, did my makeup, then let it all down. I have to say, I got some real head turns that evening. Most of the time I'll probably use this after I either air dry for awhile or use a hair dryer to get most of the wet out first. I still needed some leave-in conditioner or shine product (you can do this before or after) and if you use this for more of a straightlook, you may still want to run a flat iron on the ends, but I'm very satisfied based on my expectations for this item. BTW, I don't work for the company (I always wonder when I read a glowing review.)
  1663. Just like any new/different appliance, you will need to give yourself time to learn how to use this; once you learn the techniques you'll love it! I was pretty disappointed the first time I used it, but discovered the best way to use it (for me, at least). Most important? FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS and wait until your hair is mostly (80%) dry - seriously. This thing is not very powerful; if your hair is mostly wet you'll be wasting your time. After towel-drying, comb through then do whatever else you need to do - drink your coffee, check your email, apply your makeup, etc. Don't leave your hair wrapped up in the towel, it will take longer to air dry.<br /><br />When you're ready, put your index fingers at the top of your ears and slide them straight back, horizontally under your hair to the back of your head until your fingers meet; put all of the hair above your fingers into a clip at the top of your head. Focus only on the hair that's left hanging. Grab a section of it, turn the brush on to &#34;high&#34; and glide slowly through your hair (either above or below your hair, depending on the look you want) from roots to about an inch or two from the ends (don't brush through the ends!). While the hair is still in the brush, hold that hank of hair with your other hand and repeat this step until that length of hair is COMPLETELY dry, maybe 3-4 slow passes. On the final pass-through, continue all the day through the ends, curling the brush very slowly. Continue these steps on all of the hair that's hanging down. When it is completely dry, remove the clip, put your index fingers at your eyebrows, slide to the back of your head and clip up that hair. Then follow the same steps as above to dry the hair that's now hanging down. Once you have done this to your entire head, keep running the brush through your hair (I've always left it on &#34;high&#34;, so I don't know if &#34;low&#34; or &#34;cool&#34; will work differently) until it is COMPLETELY dry - that is very important. As you work your way up your head, it will feel like each section of hair is dry, but when you think you're all done, run your fingers through your hair - odds are it will still be very slightly damp under the thickest parts. Just keep brushing as if you were using a regular brush. If your hair is not completely dry, it will get frizzy. When I'm done, I put 2 small squirts of Frizz Ease Hair Syrum in my palms, rub them together, then run my hands down the entire length of my hair, crown to tips, focusing mostly on the ends and the areas where my layers stop.<br /><br />I spend about 5 more minutes using this dryer as opposed to my old hairdryer. After having kids, my normally stick-straight hair became wavy and frizzy; the only way to control it was to blowdry and use a curling iron. I don't have to use a curling iron after I'm done using this brush (I probably still would for special occasions though), and I've cut the time I spend on my hair every morning in half.<br /><br />Some reviewers had problems, saying the brush quit working not long after purchase. There is a 3-year warranty on it, so I did make sure I saved my receipt. The only &#34;con&#34; I've found is that it's really easy to accidentally slide the switch from &#34;high&#34; to &#34;cool&#34; as you're working, and if you're not paying close attention you might not notice it right away. The switch needs to be a little tighter so that this doesn't happen so often. Oh, and the coupon for Frizz-Ease Shampoo and Conditioner that was included in the box was already expired :( Other than that, I absolutely LOVE this brush.
  1664. Was just what I was looking for. Works to give my hair body's and nice you can use only one item instead of hair dryer and curling iron
  1665. My hairstyle does look smoother. But, the temperature does not get hot enough to do any much more dramatic than a blow dryer and a round hairbrush.The air flow should be a little faster as well. It's reputation is actually much bigger than what the hot brush can actually do. You may as well save your money.

  1668. I read about this in Cosmo and decided to give it a try. I thought the brush would grab and tangle my hair (it doesn't) or not grab it at all (it does). I have pretty thick hair, so I blow dry it 85% of the way and then style with this brush. You won't believe how easy it is and how smooth and natural looking your hair comes out! It even works on my cowlick right smack in the middle of the front of my head. From the first time I used it, I received compliments on my hair!

I found this finally awhile ago and it is super reliable, hot, and makes serious waves and smooths.<br /><br />It's almost a hair dryer but its not. It's made to be used when your hair is almost dry, about 90% or so and you can get that salon blowout look with it. This has become an every wash routine tool for me now ( I know I shouldn't because of heat damage) and I am trying to use it less, but it's so nice.<br /><br />I use heat protector and leave-in conditioner and wow. It's seriously like I came out of the salon after a great blow-out. It has three heat settings, hot, warm and cool like a dryer. The heat doesn't get so hot that you worry it will fry your hair; nothing like a flat iron at 450 degrees or anything. You can touch your hair as it dries/curls because the bristles are long and you can't touch the barrel easily. NO BURNS!<br /><br />Ionic technology and a ceramic barrel to boot. Great product for the price at $29.99 on Amazon, other places I see it range from $40-50.

  1691. In the past, I haven't liked these roller brush dryers because they took forever to dry and style my thick hair. Now, my hair has thinned and I was looking for a better style tool than just a blow dryer and roller-brush. I came across this John Frieda Hot Air Brush and decided to give it a try. After a couple month's use, I am pretty happy with it.<br /><br />I first towel-dry then air-dry while I do my makeup, or blow-dry until just damp before using the air brush. If you start from just towel-dried hair, the air brush is going to take you a long time to dry your hair completely. Then I section off my hair into four sections and use the Hot Air Brush to finish drying and styling my hair. I just do a basic blow dry with some curled ends - nothing fancy. And for this, the Air Brush does the job pretty well.<br /><br />Unlike a regular dryer and roll-brush where you are mainly blowing the top of your hair - I use this underneath the hair. This seems to help with the frizz factor. My hair wants to rebel and frizz.<br /><br />I didn't give five stars because of a few product faults: one is that the high setting gets extremely hot - so that it would very easy to scorch your hair if you are not paying attention. There is no real &#34;cool&#34; setting, just an air setting. To get a curl to set you do need the cool setting. Lastly, the switch mechanism is flat and sometimes you can't get a grip on it with your fingers if they are too dry, making it hard to switch between settings as you use it.

I have had other brands that are o.k. but the size of this brush is large enough to form a soft curl. It is not as powerful as other brands, which could be a issue if you have really thick hair.<br /><br />If a large brush is what you need, this is the tool for you.
  1744. It has made my life so much easier not to have to hold a brush in one hand and hair dryer in another to do a blow out. I have coarse, thick, wavy/curly hair. This brush left it smooth and shiny in a short period of time. It has been especially useful for the back of my head and the bottom near my neck, which has always been the most difficult to blow out. As I'm getting used to it, I can easily do my hair at the nape of the neck with one hand and it doesn't get so hot that I have to worry about burning myself. Also, I've had no problem with the controls on the front, as some reviewers have mentioned.

Also, the price is very good, compared to the Instyler, which is expensive and very drying to the hair (too drying, in my opinion, to use daily/regularly). The John Frieda has high heat, but not scorching, which works very well for straightening curly hair.<br />The Con's: It gives my hair &#34;static&#34; and leaves my fine hair kind of &#34;flat&#34;. It does such a great job of straightening, it leaves it a little too straight/without body. I live in L.A. and the air is dry, which may contribute to the static as well, although I don't get it with the other dryers. I think that if I tinted my hair, it would be perfect for me (not doing it though).<br /><br />Bottom Line: I recommend it! I continue to use this hot air brush, and alternate with the Conair, which is better at giving me &#34;body&#34;.

  1803. I bought this over 6 months ago; I have fine to medium thick hair, past my shoulders. I'm not great at blow-drying my hair and always found it difficult to blow out my long layers,especially around my face. This brush has made an unbelievable difference. Most days, I dry my hair about 80%, upside down first with a blow dryer. I then section off the top/crown part of my hair and use a blow-dryer and big round brush to blow out and smooth the rest of my hair. I then use the hot air brush to do the top and front of my hair. I went on youtube to get instructions on how to blow dry hair and use these to do the top with the hot air brush, instead of a regular brush. Nothing difficult. Just get a section and roll it around the hot air brush. I use heat for about 1 minute then another 30 seconds of cold air. It turns out really well! When I have more time, I use this brush to dry all my hair, section by section. I then use a small amount of John Frieda frizz-ease smoothing cream and it looks amazing.Bouncy and wavy but not curly. I'd give this 5 stars but the only drawback was the motor burned out after 6 months. I tried another hot brush..not even close to this quality and returned it. I contacted Conair who replaced the hot air brush, no problem. You won't regret buying this, it's changed my life, seriously.

Gets the job done fast, doesn't damage my fine hair either. To clean it I simply run a dampened, stiff nail brush through the bristles, removing hair and styling residue. I once cleaned it a bit more thoroughly by using a very wet nailbrush and two drops of shampoo; brushed it through the bristles, then rinsed it running the wet, soap-free nail brush through the bristles several times. I allowed it to dry thoroughly, plugged it in and voila! Not only did it work great, it was clean as a whistle. Too bad there isn't a better way of taking this apart to clean it completely without damage to the electrical source.

  1855. Happy with this purchase. I have the type of hair that if left to dry on it's own is a wavy-ish frizz mess. The difference I've noticed since using it, is that my hair has more overall lift from the roots and the bottom can curl in or out as I want it. Previously, I was using a large round brush. Unlike some reviewers, I have long since mastered the blow drier + round brush combo. But, the problems that I've experienced with that method are: using both arms, above the head and for extended periods, is painful/ labor intensive/ exhausting; it takes a long time; and it's hot as bloody hell. And frankly, the results aren't great with long hair. When I had a rounded bob, it was perfect, but since my hair has gotten longer, it's just meh. But this hot air brush it different. This is quick, you can do it one-handed, and I didn't even break a sweat, literally. My hair looks shiny and curled. In short, I love it.

Great results and no tangling. Then I add a bit of Aveda's Light Elements Smoothing Fluid and do a quick (5-minute) touch up with my flat iron.   1883. I have no idea what possessed me to consider buying this item, I have a very expensive blow drier that works just fine, but based on the reviews here and on some of my favorite bloggers sites, I was intrigued. The price point was low enough that I figured if it didn't work well enough, I'd keep it as a back up in the guest bath. I chose this particular one over others mainly because of the brand and the sleek look. It's very light, so light that I thought it wouldn't work good enough. Once I turned it on, the air felt so weak that I thought there'd be no way for it get my thick, sopping hair dry. I picked a small section of hair and rolled my hair around the ends a few times and realized it was working! I couldn't believe it! It cuts my hair drying time almost in half because there's no fussing with holding the blow drier and the brush at the same time. You have a lot more control over the sections and it makes it so much easier to get volume at the top and curl the ends nicely at the bottom. Since purchasing, I have not used my traditional blow drier at all. I will say that this hot air brush is only good if you want to do your hair straight or with the ends flipped up, you can't really use it to blow the cold out of your hair or anything, so you'll still need a traditional blow drier if you want to just blow air through your hair. This is absolutely the perfect tool to get your hair looking like a salon style blow out.

  1892. For years I had tried different shampoos/conditioners to try to replicate that shiny, silky hair that I walked away from the salon with -- all to no avail! Not only is it a wonderful help for my arthritic left hand -- but now, when I blow dry my hair, it looks like I had it done at the salon! It is shiny and silky and no longer looks like straw -- and all this from a hot air brush! I am absolutely blown away (pardon the pun!)!<br /><br />I have even tried using different kinds of shampoo (since I have so many from my search for that shiny, supple hair), but it still comes out beautifully every time. I will tell you that I use a little Redken Outshine 01 before I blow dry it -- but I was using that when it turned out as a frizzy mess, too! PLEASE NOTE: I wash my hair, towel dry it, comb it out and then put on my make-up before blow drying my hair. I also section it off using one of those larger claw clips, starting at the base of my neck and dry it in sections like they do at the salon. It does take a little longer than my old way of doing it -- but the results are MORE than worth a few extra minutes, in my humble opinion. Hope this helps in your search!

I have shoulder length hair that's very thick and curly, I also have nappy hairs here and there. Every time I did my hair with this product, my hair came out very frizzy. My hair takes an hour in a half to do. But with this product, even if I spent an extra hour on it, the result is always the same, I get frizzy hair.   1936. I love this product. I don't have the time or patience for a perfect blowout using a blow dryer and round brush, and this makes it incredibly easy and quick. I love that it doesn't spin - I had a similar (but cheap) hot air brush growing up that spun, and I always ended up with horrible tangles.<br />As with most hair styling tools, it takes some trial and error to master your technique (especially if it's totally new to you), so give it a few tries before deciding whether it's for you or not. This gives you the control over how much curl you want to add to your hair, in a very simple and quick way. If you just run it through your hair, you will end up with a bouncy but straight style with just a little bend at the ends (gorgeous). If you want more curl, hold it vertically and keep turning it through your hair as you go through the length of it (NEVER wrap the hair around it, just brush it through). You can also get a &#34;Farrah&#34; 'do by curling away from your face and concentrating on the ends.<br />I have very thick hair, so I always do a &#34;rough&#34; dry first, drying my hair about 75-80% before starting with the hot air brush. It makes the process go a lot faster, and you really only need the hot hair brush to finish the job.<br />This has 3 settings, low, high, and cool. I use high on most of my hair, low on the front (I don't want to damage the thinner &#34;baby&#34; hair), and I rarely use the cool setting. It works just as well and is faster to give my hair a shot of cold hair from the regular blowdryer once the style is finished to set it.<br />You'll love this product for the time it saves you after the shower and for all the hair style possibilities.
  1937. The very best hair appliance ever for medium length, keratin and color treated hair. Love it!
  1938. Doing my hair never was easier or less frustrating! THANK YOU!!!<br /><br />And, to Amazon, who carries almost everything I need; thank you, too!
  1945. I recently cut my hair from shoulder length to a bob just below my ears. I absolutely love the cut, but was having a hard time getting it to look good. After wearing my hair in a pony-tail for a million years, I just wasn't doing a very good job of getting the back of my hair straight and curled under with a round brush and blow-dryer (my hair is very wavy when wet...if it's not dried properly, it tends to look frizzy and matted. Hence the pony-tail for 12+ years).<br /><br />I tried a flat iron, but never really felt comfortable with it. I initially searched for the InStyler rotating brush, but never found it here on Amazon. This brush came up as a recommendation though, and after watching a YouTube video on how it works, decided to go for it. I am so, so happy with this purchase. I absolutely LOVE it.<br /><br />It's easy to use, I have so much more control over how my hair gets dried since both hands aren't being utilized by a separate brush and dryer, and I find that I'm spending less time drying and styling my hair since I can now work faster.<br /><br />I cannot recommend this enough. I can't comment on all hair types, but if you have shorter fine hair, this is amazing. I'm actually going to buy a second one just to have as a back-up. I'm not worried about it crapping out on me anytime soon, but I'd hate for it to die one day, and I find that it's no longer available. This has quickly become my most important styling tool.
  1946. I have thin and fine hair and find this product dries hair really slowly, though I have already blow dried my hair half way.<br />Really like the light weighted design, but this doesn't work for me. 500WATTS just way less powerful.
  1947. I have natural curly hair. This is the best product I have ever used. It combines dryer & flat iron which cuts the time in half to style your hair.
  1948. I can't live without this thing! I have short to medium-length hair, and I'm useless at the old dryer / round brush routine that they do at the salon after a cut, but this makes my hair look just as good, and it's so easy. Perfect size for getting soft, natural, curled-under ends and a little lift at the roots.
  1949. Was hoping it was self spinning, other than that does give volume to my hair
  1950. This hot air brush works really well without damaging my hair. I have very thin hair and using this tool to style after partial blowdrying upside down works for volume!
  1951. This is one of those hair curlers that you have to wrap your hair around the stem rather than having a clip to hold your hair.   1953. I really like this product. I have never been able to dry my hair like my stylist does - with both hands!!! Now, with this dryer, I can separate my hair into sections, dry, and the finished product is a smoother, more frizz free hair style.
