  1954. This is the best hot air brush I've owned. The large barrel is great. I highly recommend it for any length of hair.
  1955. I bought this after reading the reviews, and I am so happy I did! I should mention that this brush does not have the automatic roll up, you roll it manually instead. That was actually a nice surprise...one less thing to worry about while drying your hair. I have thick silver hair, and have it cut into a short bob cut...this thing created the most volume I've ever gotten. I use 'Big Sexy Hair Root Booster' which I spray in sections on the roots, and after drying with this brush, I don't even have to flat iron the ends if I don't feel like it. My hair is so full, bouncy and the shine is amazing. It's well worth the price, I may buy another one to have on hand in case they stop making this. LOVE it!
  1956. Great size but not enough power. It takes way to long and I wish I would have returned it before using. I can do much better with a round brush and blow dryer.
  1957. This is one of the best investment that I have made for my hair. It is fast and my hair is soft, shiny and manageable. I would highly recommend the air brush.
  1958. Pretty much as described. The only reservation I have is that it tends to get a little too hot on the high heat function.<br />I would probably recommend using this on medium heat to protect hair from heat damage.
  1959. I shampoo my hair only twice a week and use the traditional blow dryer and round brush for drying. However, I could not do without my round hot air brush for in-between touch-ups. I've used one for years and it brings my hair back to looking freshly done. The reason for the not-perfect rating for this brush is because I have fine hair and the John Frieda brush makes it too smooth and flat. For the person wanting flat, straight hair, I think it would be perfect. For me, I'll have to stick to my non-tourmaline hot air brush. My daughter-in-law got my John Frieda dryer brush and loves it.   1960. What a great product. I wish it had been available years ago. I have soft, natural curly hair, and this brush leaves my hair bouncy, shiny and styled for several days. I suggest you blow dry the excess water from your roots on down before using this brush to style your hair. This step speeds up your blow out time.
  1961. I am a 42 year old female who has fine brown hair, which I color blond and is cut in a bob to around shoulder length. My family has a history of arthritis, which is effecting me in my hands for the past 5 years but has recently gotten progressively worse. Thus, I am looking for things which I can do to put less stress on my hands.<br /><br />For my hairstyle and hair type, I shampoo and blow dry my hair every day. In order to get the style as needed, I use a round brush with a hairdryer. But, it's painful for me to hold and turn the brush to dry my hair. And, as a result, I end up not drying it all of the way which makes it frizzy and makes me cold in the winter!<br /><br />I was looking around on Amazon for products which might be able to help ease the effort my hands while still allowing for me to maintain the hairstyle that I like. I saw this product and read the reviews and thought that I would give it a try. I love it!<br /><br />First, it is VERY LIGHTWEIGHT which is great for hands. It is the size of a large round brush and in the middle of the brush, there are small holes which is where the air blows out from just like a hairdryer. It has different speeds - Low Heat, High Heat and Cool (for setting the style). It is important to note that the heat on the High Heat setting is not as hot as a regular hair dry and this is intention - you are holding this brush right next to your scalp to try the hair and so it can't be as hot as a regular hair dryer. I have no issues with this as my hair is fine and it dries it just fine. I have chosen to use my regular hair dryer with my fingers to take most of the wetness out of the my hair first, and then I use this to finish drying it and styling it at the same time.<br /><br />Although it sounds like more work, it actually takes me less time because I do not have to the flat iron after my hair is dry as this brush dryer allows for me to smooth the hair while drying it which is great.<br /><br /> I am not sure how well that it would work for someone with very thick hair - you may want to do what I did and dry it first by air or with a hair dryer and then finish up the style with this product.<br /><br />But, for me, I absolutely love this product and highly recommend it.w well that it would work for someone with very thick hair - you may want to do what I did and dry it first by air or with a hair dryer and then finish up the style with this product.<br /><br />But, for me, I absolutely love this product and highly recommend it.
  1962. I am not a daily hair dryer user; generally I air dry and may use a brush and hair dryer to style a bit once my hair is mostly dry. This is the perfect combination for my method.   1980. As a real estate broker/ owner this product has liberate me and will be the only hair dryer needed when I can get away. It well worth the investment. Ladies, leave hair In Towel for 10 mins. Section the front, mid and back. Dry front, then mid and back section. Dry the section of the roots front and back first, the mid section of the hair and last roll the ends then bump. My hair was bouncy and professional looking after 40 mins. My husband could not believed the transformation with the product as I did. Thank you John.

  1999. See my review on the other top hot air brush contender here, [[ASIN:B004INUWX0 Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler, Black]]: http://www.amazon.com/review/ROMGY956S8H6L/ref=cm_cr_pr_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B004INUWX0&linkCode=&nodeID=&tag=<br /><br />I'm no beginner when it comes to hair tools but I've never been able to master the art of a blow dryer and a round brush. Randomly I ran across this product as well as the Conair Infinitipro styler. Initially I thought this rotated like the Conair version but it does not. Turns out what I thought I wanted doesn't work like I expected and the John Frieda version is much, much better.<br /><br />If you don't want to read the whole review the bottom line is this: For a true salon quality looking blow out, go with the John Frieda device and NOT the Conair rotating hair brush.<br /><br />---- After several comments, I'd like to add that your mileage will probably vary according to your hair type. I have long (mid-back), semi-thick wavy hair. This may have something to do with why the different stylers had such different results. The Conair just couldn't get through my hair----<br /><br />I did a (literal) side by side comparison of the [[ASIN:B004INUWX0 Infinitipro Spin Air Rotating Styler, Black]] and the [[ASIN:B0056GDG90 John Frieda JFHA5 Hot Air Brush, 1.5 inch]]. Let's just say after 30 minutes or so on one side with the Infinitipro brush, I gave up. That was even on the side that I typically find easier to style. The side that's more difficult I tackled with the John Frieda brush and then went back to fix what the Infinitipro just couldn't do. I did all that in the time it took me to get less than mediocre results with the one side of the Infinitipro brush. Anywho, the overall summary of the John Frieda device:<br /><br />Pros:<br />- The hair dryer actually does a decent job of drying while it styles<br />- The bristles are sturdy and add shine but also allows for more precision in defining layers and getting the curl right where you want it<br />- No tangles!<br />- Controls frizz and makes it easy to avoid the weird waves and curls that occur near the roots with traditional hair drying. Even easy to get the back of your head!<br />- Can easily maneuver different sections of hair without having to put the brush down. Although this sounds really basic and a bit silly, I didn't appreciate it until I tried the Conair rotating brush where I had to put it down then very carefully section out hair so random hairs wouldn't get caught in the spinning frenzy.<br />- I have long, naturally wavy hair that is fine but there's lots of it. Unlike most tools, brushes, etc. the JF brush had no problem managing the layers and truly making it look like the beautiful end curling that you get in a true blow out. I went back and fixed the frizzy mess the Conair did to my hair with the JF brush.<br />- Light and easy to maneuver.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The tip on the top gets very hot. Although I don't need it often, it would be nice if this was some sort of heat resistant or silicon coated topper so when I need to hold it for certain angles, I can.<br />- I wish the actual brush area was a little bit longer- just a smidge. It does the job though<br /><br />Why the John Frieda brush is better than the Conair Infinitipro rotating brush:<br />- Easy to handle, easy to maneuver, and fits in your hand. The Infinitipro is clunky, large, and more often than not, I found myself hitting the wrong darn button and creating a crazy unexpected rat's nest<br />- It's pretty darn fast whereas the Conair took FOREVER and didn't even do a good job. Like I said above, I used the JF to fix the frizz & limp looking curls caused by the Conair<br />- Brush bristles are stiffer but still do not tangle. The more rigid bristles allow for better defined curls & layers as well as more control over the angles and getting the smooth, straight look of a blow out<br />- Although the hair dryer probably won't replace the power of your typical hair dryer, the John Frieda is leaps and bounds better than the Conair. Parts of my hair, especially near the roots, was still slightly damp after using the Infinitipro for nearly 30 minutes on only one side. The JF brush took care of that in a few minutes.<br /><br />All in all, don't waste your time wondering about the Infinitipro, just go with the John Frieda brush. It is leaps and bounds better.r typical hair dryer, the John Frieda is leaps and bounds better than the Conair. Parts of my hair, especially near the roots, was still slightly damp after using the Infinitipro for nearly 30 minutes on only one side. The JF brush took care of that in a few minutes.<br /><br />All in all, don't waste your time wondering about the Infinitipro, just go with the John Frieda brush. It is leaps and bounds better.
  2000. I ordered this hairbrush due to reviews and 1 1/2 inch size. It did a perfect salon finish to my thick slightly wavy hair in a third the time of using a hair dryer and curing iron or flat iron. Since it is summer I let my hair dry about half way then used this brush. It did not make my hair to hot and did not tangle. I did not try to curl hair. I just wanted a smooth straight finish with a little bend in the ends. It was a miracle. It is also nice to work with such a light piece of equipment. I am so glad I found this and love it.
  2001. Finally - one product that can straighten and dry at the same time! I dry my hair until almost dry and then I use this to finish the straightening and light curl on the end. I have weak arms and this really saves them! I should probably buy another one just incase they stop making them.
